LitPathExplorer supports pathway modellers and curators alike by: (i) extracting events from the literature that corroborate existing models with evidence; (ii) discovering new events which can update models; and (iii) providing a confidence value for each event that is automatically computed based on linguistic features and article metadata. \n\nhttps://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btx774", Brighton et al., PNAS 2017 \nDOI: 10.1073/pnas.1714532114\n\nadditional falcon footage and images\nCaroline Brighton\nvideoblocks\npond5\n\nmusic\n\"Is that you or are you you\"\nChris Zabriskie", "channelId": "UCv0aU2eKry3kdSTnFa8QAWA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "603", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "30", "viewCount": "72901", "dislikeCount": "14"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M58S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044", "q": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044", "items": [{"id": "v2TXCGxnOkQ", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Robin Mills", "tags": ["peregrine falcon stoop"], "title": "Stoop of the peregrine falcon in a bird flight simulator", "publishedAt": "2018-04-11T12:18:56Z", "description": "http://www.robin-mills.com\nWitnessing the high-speed stoop of a peregrine falcon is impressive: a falcon may first soar at altitudes of several hundred meters, up to several kilometers above their prey. Then, within the blink of an eye, it dives down \u2013 first flapping forcefully and then folding its wings to decrease drag. It basically appears to drop out the sky. When the falcon nears its prey, it may knock its prey with a massive blow, or catch it with its talons. Here, I simulated the behavior in a flight simulator I built for my PhD. The simulation incorporates the aerodynamics of bird flight, how birds flap and tuck their wings, how falcons perceive their prey and react to it with delay and how falcons target their prey like a missile.\n\nFor the paper, see:\nhttp://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044\n\nFor the code of the simulator, see: https://gitlab.com/BirdFlightSimulator/BirdFlightSimulation", "channelId": "UCsEOS66qW4OBGuiKTshiupA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "20", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "3", "viewCount": "14445", "dislikeCount": "3"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT21S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044", "q": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044", "items": [{"id": "tO0mqbZEH4o", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["PLoS Comput Biol", "Bird flight", "Wings", "Predation", "Acceleration", "Flight", "Starlings", "Birds", "Aerodynamics", "Falco peregrinus"], "title": "Physics-based simulations of aerial attacks by peregrine falcons reveal that stooping at high speed", "publishedAt": "2018-04-12T20:02:27Z", "description": "Physics-based simulations of aerial attacks by peregrine falcons reveal that stooping at high speed maximizes catch success against agile prey. Robin Mills et al (2018), PLoS Comput Biol https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006044\n\nThe peregrine falcon Falco peregrinus is renowned for attacking its prey from high altitude in a fast controlled dive called a stoop. Many other raptors employ a similar mode of attack, but the functional benefits of stooping remain obscure. Here we investigate whether, when, and why stooping promotes catch success, using a three-dimensional, agent-based modeling approach to simulate attacks of falcons on aerial prey. We simulate avian flapping and gliding flight using an analytical quasi-steady model of the aerodynamic forces and moments, parametrized by empirical measurements of flight morphology. The model-birds\u2019 flight control inputs are commanded by their guidance system, comprising a phenomenological model of its vision, guidance, and control. To intercept its prey, model-falcons use the same guidance law as missiles (pure proportional navigation); this assumption is corroborated by empirical data on peregrine falcons hunting lures. We parametrically vary the falcon\u2019s starting position relative to its prey, together with the feedback gain of its guidance loop, under differing assumptions regarding its errors and delay in vision and control, and for three different patterns of prey motion. We find that, when the prey maneuvers erratically, high-altitude stoops increase catch success compared to low-altitude attacks, but only if the falcon\u2019s guidance law is appropriately tuned, and only given a high degree of precision in vision and control. Remarkably, the optimal tuning of the guidance law in our simulations coincides closely with what has been observed empirically in peregrines. High-altitude stoops are shown to be beneficial because their high airspeed enables production of higher aerodynamic forces for maneuvering, and facilitates higher roll agility as the wings are tucked, each of which is essential to catching maneuvering prey at realistic response delays.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "153", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M31S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006109", "q": "10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006109", "items": [{"id": "GMVEDgeNwfw", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Benjamin M Friedrich", "tags": ["sperm", "chemotaxis", "decision theory", "biophysics"], "title": "Decision making improves sperm chemotaxis in the presence of noise", "publishedAt": "2019-06-25T07:15:15Z", "description": "Simulated swimming path of a sperm cell, displaying dynamic switching between two different steering modes (displayed red and black), to cope with strong sensory noise while navigating in a concentration gradient of signaling molecules (blue) released from an egg cell (yellow). \n\nFrom our paper: \nJustus A. Zhong Feng Gao et al (2018), NPG Asia Materials https://doi.org/10.1038/s41427-018-0024-7\n\nHerein, we demonstrate a contact angle (CA)-based naked-eye point-of-care testing platform with rapid pH-responsive superwettability that can switch between superhydrophilic and superhydrophobic properties for quantitative biosensing. The CA of the droplet on the pH-responsive surface approached ~0\u00b0 at pH 1 and conversely reached 161.4\u00b0\u2009\u00b1\u20096.2\u00b0 at pH 13. We realized the sensitive detection of the pH, urea, and glucose by monitoring the changes in the CA. The traditional invasive diagnosis of diabetes causes pain and brings the risk of infections, such as acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and syphilis, to the user. To address this issue, we implemented a method for the non-invasive diagnosis of diabetes in human saliva and urine, which avoided the significant drawbacks mentioned above. The accuracy of this method was demonstrated by comparing the results with those from commercial glucometers and theoretical calculations. Interestingly, we successfully monitored glucose levels in sweat before, during, and after cycling. The sensing performance was barely influenced by the temperature, elevation, and droplet color, illustrating promise for expansion to hundreds of millions of potential customers, especially those with color blindness or color weakness. Given its low cost, lack of instruments, and rapid response (within 1\u2009s), this strategy might overcome the limitations of the mechanical stability and durability of superwettable materials and thus might extend the industrial-scale application of bioinspired superwettable systems.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "36", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M29S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1038/s41427-018-0026-5", "q": "10.1038/s41427-018-0026-5", "items": [{"id": "0DJo6OseYH8", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["Electronics", "photonics and device physics", "Fluidics", "Nanophotonics and plasmonics", "Optical properties and devices", "NPG Asia Materials"], "title": "Hybrid optofluidics and three-dimensional manipulation based on hybrid photothermal waveguides", "publishedAt": "2018-04-20T18:14:04Z", "description": "Hybrid optofluidics and three-dimensional manipulation based on hybrid photothermal waveguides. Jiapeng Zheng et al (2018), NPG Asia Materials https://doi.org/10.1038/s41427-018-0026-5\n\nDespite enormous breakthroughs in lab-on-a-chip techniques, light-driven manipulation faces two long-standing challenges: the ability to achieve both multiform manipulation and tunable manipulation range and the means to avoid potential thermal damage to the targets. By harnessing the optical heating of hybrid photothermal waveguides (HPW), we develop a hybrid optofluidic technique involving buoyancy and thermocapillary convection to achieve fluid transport with controllable modes and tunable strength. Switching of the optofluidic mode from buoyancy to thermocapillary convection, namely, from vertical to horizontal vortices, is employed for three-dimensional manipulation. The strong confinement and torque in the vortices are capable of trapping and rotating/spinning particles at the vortex centers rather than the HPW. Buoyancy convection provides a trapping circle to achieve collective trapping and vertical rotation/spin, while thermocapillary convection offers a trapping lattice to achieve distributed trapping and horizontal rotation/spin. By integrating micro/nanoparticles with various properties and sizes, further investigations of the optofluidic arrangement, mixing, and synthesis will broaden the potential applications of the hybrid optofluidic technique in the fields of lab-on-a-chip, materials science, chemical synthesis and analysis, photonics, and nanoscience.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "69", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1038/s41427-018-0029-2", "q": "10.1038/s41427-018-0029-2", "items": [{"id": "H7Y68mAY9dU", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["NPG Asia Materials", "Electronic devices", "Sensors and biosensors"], "title": "A highly sensitive and moisture-resistant gas sensor for diabetes diagnosis with Pt@In2O3 nanowires", "publishedAt": "2018-04-17T17:51:41Z", "description": "A highly sensitive and moisture-resistant gas sensor for diabetes diagnosis with Pt@In2O3 nanowires and a molecular sieve for protection. Wei Liu et al (2018), NPG Asia Materials https://doi.org/10.1038/s41427-018-0029-2\n\nSensitive and selective detection of acetone in human exhaled breath plays an important role in the diagnosis of diabetes. However, obtaining a reliable response to ppb levels of acetone and avoiding cross-sensitivity due to the large amount of moisture in exhaled breath are still great challenges. In this work, a type of acetone sensor with ultrahigh sensitivity and moisture resistance is reported. Electrospun In2O3 nanowires with a controllable Pt core (Pt@In2O3 core-shell nanowires) are designed and prepared as sensitive layers. A mesoporous silica molecular sieve is further integrated as the moisture filter layer. The Pt@In2O3 core-shell nanowire-based sensor exhibits a highly improved response compared with a sensor based on pure In2O3 nanowires due to the probable increase in surface resistance and the introduction of p\u2013n junctions after rational design of the structure. In addition, a good performance in terms of the fast dynamic process, selectivity and long-term stability is also achieved, and the detection limit can be as low as 10\u2009ppb, which is much lower than the concentration level of 1.8\u2009ppm in the exhaled breath of diabetic patients. The influence of the large amount of moisture is greatly weakened by using the molecular sieve as a moisture filter layer, leading to much improved sensitivity in clinical sample detection among healthy and diabetic patients. Based on the optimized composite structure of the Pt@In2O3 core-shell nanowire sensor and moisture filter layer, a simple portable sensing prototype is successfully fabricated. The reported Pt@In2O3 core-shell nanowires and the acetone sensing approach open up a new opportunity for a simple, inexpensive, and noninvasive diagnosis of diabetes.\n\nGood channel: "MIfAVTDvM2o", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "\u0414\u043e\u043a\u0442\u043e\u0440 \u0421\u0435\u0440\u0433\u0435\u0439 \u0420\u0443\u0441\u0430\u043d\u043e\u0432", "tags": ["Atherosclerosis", "Cylindrical plaques", "pathological increase of level of LDL in the blood", "level of LDL in the blood", "cerebral stroke", "cardiac infarction"], "title": "Atherosclerosis? No!!!  Cylindrical cholesterol plaque!!! Pathophysiology", "publishedAt": "2018-05-14T13:01:47Z", "description": "Today there is a deadly error in medicine. Patients with acute heart attacks and strokes, as well as physicians therapists do not know important information.\n\nBecause of this error, several million people die each year. Millions of people become disabled.\n\nTherapists and cardiologists are 100% sure that they are treating atherosclerosis. But this is a mistake.\n\nIn the vessels of the heart and brain with acute disruption of blood circulation - there is no atherosclerotic plaque.\n\nThe cause of an acute stroke and an acute infarction is a completely different cholesteric plaque.\n\nSoft, elastic, appears quickly (in a few days).\n\nA soft cholesterol plaque can be treated before surgery. Cholesterol plaque easily disappears, easily stretches.\n\nThis is \"atherosclerosis.\"\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arteriosclerosis\n\u00abArteriosclerosis is the thickening, hardening and loss of elasticity of the walls of arteries. This process gradually restricts the blood flow to one's organs and tissues and can lead to severe health risks brought on by atherosclerosis, which is a specific form of arteriosclerosis caused by the buildup of fatty plaques, cholesterol, and some other substances in and on the artery walls\u00bb wikipedia.\n\nThis is what really is in the vessel.\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DR03TWR06ng    1:40- 3:07\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fGw0oBmmuHM   0:27 , 2:06-2:15\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CE2UMvOvWnU   2:04- 2:35   \n -https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wQ1yIT8dt3Y  25:13- 25:46  cholesteric plaque  - \n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R8dVYf-LV44&feature=youtu.be 4:58, 13:51\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqx_19N6eWA&feature=youtu.be 1:52 -2:15\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=arZiYgt200M&feature=youtu.be 17:58- 20:23\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5n3npP1a58E&feature=youtu.be 58:15, 59:22,1:11:44\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oa8XV27KNAY&feature=youtu.be, 00:54, 11:05\n- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wYpyj97Jmxg&feature=youtu.be 0:47\n\n\n\nThis plaque kills, makes people with disabilities, increases the level of bad cholesterol in the blood.\nMedical Hypotheses 106 (2017) 61\u201370  \nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.mehy.2017.07.001\n \nIn this article is given the new insight about the affection of stress on the increase of level of low density\nlipoproteins (LDL) in the blood, which is connected with the disturbance of hydrodynamics in the bloodstream,\nthe attention was paid to the cylindrical cholesterol plaque, and it\u2019s classification. The disturbance\nof hydrodynamics of blood under the stress leads to the formation of a cylindrical cholesterol\nplaque, which repeats the contour of the vessel, and leads to the ischemic disorders of the heart and\nbrain. The cylindrical cholesterol plaque goes through several stages of development: friable, yielding,\ndense, old. In the case of destruction of friable, fresh cholesterol plaque, releases a big quantity of lowdensity\nlipoproteins. This leads to the pathological increase of level of LDL in the blood. In the case of long\ndisturbance of hydrodynamics, occurs the formation of strong links between low-density lipoproteins.\nYielding cholesterol plaque is formed. Further maturation of cylindrical cholesterol plaque, leads to it\u2019s\ndensifying and damage.\nWe may emphasize, that short periods of strong contraction and expansion of vessels lead to the\nincrease of level of LDL in the blood. Self-dependent restoration of normal level of LDL in blood occurs\nin the case of restoration of pressure in the limits of numbers, which are specific for particular person,\nand which don\u2019t exceed the physiological standard.\nAmong patients with long duration of stress, the duration of vasospasm increases. LDL, without having\na possibility to crumble, begin to stick together and form the yielding cylindrical plaque. It is characterized\nby having of not so strong connection with the vascular wall, and maintains only at the expanse of\niteration of the vascular wall, it has cylindrical shape, is elastic and yellow. The thickness and length of\nwalls depends on the degree of cross-clamping during the time of formation of yielding cylindrical plaque.\nIn the case of stopping of spasm, yielding cylindrical plaque can resolve slowly.\nAmong hypotensive and individuals, which have normal pressure, the increase of level of LDL isn\u2019t\nnoted. There aren\u2019t such investigations, where such link was noted. The increasing of level of LDL among\nthese people (especially under the stress) can say about cases of short-term increase of pressure, which\ncould be unnoticed. These patients require pressure monitoring and, accordingly, the adjustment of the\nstate of stress and anger.", "channelId": "UCrqynjYO6-v8zu7fHxIyLEQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "7", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "8", "viewCount": "426", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M2S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.04.007", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.04.007", "items": [{"id": "71E7liHAJ2M", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "NutritionFacts.org", "tags": ["toxoplasmosis", "toxoplasmosis treatment", "toxoplasmosis cure", "toxoplasmosis causes", "Brain parasites", "Foodborne parasites", "Parasite cleanse diet", "Anti parasite diet", "How not to die", "Nutrition facts", "Nutritionfacts.org", "Dr Greger", "Michael Greger", "Dr Michael Greger", "Dr Gregor"], "title": "How to Prevent Toxoplasmosis", "publishedAt": "2019-05-29T12:03:29Z", "description": "The risk of contracting the brain parasite toxoplasma from kitty litter vs. meat.\n\nSubscribe to NutritionFacts.org's free newsletter to receive our fasting infographic that covers the latest research on the risks and benefits of different types of fasting: https://nutritionfacts.org/subscribe.\n\nHere\u2019s the \u201cdaily dozen\u201d thing I mentioned: Dr. Greger\u2019s Daily Dozen Checklist (https://nutritionfacts.org/video/dr-gregers-daily-dozen-checklist/).\n\nOf course this is not the only reason to make sure you get enough vitamin B12. The path to printing an organ is far from easy though and many problems have to be solved with regards to bioprinters, bioinks and capillary formation in the organ. \n\nA big thanks to the Wake Forest Institure for Renegerative medicine and Dr. Anthony Atala for the footage and images on the bioprinting process:\nhttps://school.wakehealth.edu/Research/Institutes-and-Centers/Wake-Forest-Institute-for-Regenerative-Medicine\n\nThe Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine is recognized as an international leader in translating scientific discovery into clinical therapies, with many world firsts, including the development and implantation of the first engineered organ in a patient. More than 450 scientists collaborate on regenerative medicine research at the institute, the largest in the world, working on more than 40 different tissues and organs. The institute is part of Wake Forest University and is located in the Innovation Quarter in downtown Winston-Salem, NC. Through partnerships and collaborations with many regenerative medicine centers internationally, the institute, which is driven by the urgent needs of patients, is making a global difference in the world of regenerative medicine.\n\nResources \n\nMagazine stories etc. on bioprinters: \n\nAn interesting Guardian article on bioprinting and bioprinting startups:\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jul/30/will-3d-printing-solve-the-organ-transplant-shortage\n\nA conversation with Dr. Stephanie Willerth, a researcher in biomedical engineering, about the state of bioprinting and the implications of the technology. https://www.3dprintingmedia.network/lets-get-real-what-can-we-bioprint-and-what-is-just-media-hype/\n\nShorter blog posts on 3D bioprinting in general:\nhttps://www.lifecyclebio.com/2018/07/27/3d-bioprinting-the-state-of-the-art-in-regenerative-medicine/\nhttps://www.sculpteo.com/blog/2018/02/21/3d-bioprinting-what-can-we-achieve-today-with-a-3d-bioprinter/\nhttps://all3dp.com/brief-introduction-3d-bioprinting/\n\nAn overview of the different 3D bioprinting companies \nhttps://medicalfuturist.com/top-bioprinting-companies\n\n--\n\nOther articles and resources\n\nThe global market for 3D bioprinting is estimated to reach 1 billion dollars by the early 2020's \nhttps://blog.marketresearch.com/3d-bioprinting-a-revolutionary-technology-in-the-healthcare-industry\n\nA review article on the integrated tissue organ printer and on the ear construct printed with it at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine:\nhttps://doi.org/10.1038/nbt.3413\n\nA review article on the different approaches to bioinks:\nhttps://doi.org/10.1557/mrs.2017.164\n\nOPEN ACCESS - A thorough article on different 3D bioprinting methods and bioinks\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.bioactmat.2017.11.008\n\nAnother very thorough review article focusing on the different tissue types being printed. Shifts in modes of governance are described, along with some key concerns related to mobilities and hyper-neoliberism. The paper raises the question of what constitutes good governance in the context of good tourism (e.g., sustainable tourism, responsible tourism, pro-poor tourism). Drawing on case research as well as theoretical influences, it forwards for future consideration justice as a key principle for good governance and policy in tourism. The importance of cultural values, and of addressing the historical context are noted. The Critical Opinion also calls on researchers to engage with diverse theoretical perspectives and research methodologies that can help facilitate \u201cjust governance\u201d to tourism.\n\nAccess: "channelTitle": "Ohio State Environmental Professionals Network", "title": "March 17, 2020: Exploring the Interactions between Water, Climate and Communication", "publishedAt": "2020-03-20T19:23:25Z", "description": "On Tuesday March 17, EPN hosted a Zoom Webinar-based program instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nThis EPN Zoom Webinar-based program, co-hosted with the Water Management Association of Ohio (WMAO), the Ohio Water Resources Center, and TerrAqua (a multi-disciplinary student organization at Ohio State), occurred through an online format instead of our standard EPN in-person breakfast program. \n\nNumerous research agencies, including the U.S. Global Change Research Program, find that in the U.S. Midwest a variety of weather-related challenges are currently, and will increasingly, impact our local communities through such issues as extreme precipitation events and flooding, decreases in lake ice and snow cover, and increases in urban heat islands and drought nca2018.globalchange.gov/chapter/21/). These water-climate relationships are complex, dynamic and can be challenging to communicate. \n\nJoin this program as we learn about the interactions between the water cycle, changing weather patterns, and how to understand and communicate these issues in natural resource management. This program is in alignment with the March 22, 2020 World Water Day theme, which is \u201cabout water and climate change \u2013 and how the two are inextricably linked.\u201d (learn more at worldwaterday.org). Thanks to our colleagues at the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at Ohio State for helping to frame this program\u2019s agenda.\n\nThis program features: \n\nJoe Campbell, Ph.D. director, EPN, Hannah Comune, president, TerrAqua, and Eugene Braig, program director of aquatic ecosystems (SENR) and board president, WMAO, provide welcome remarks and program introduction\n\nBryan Mark, Ph.D., professor, Department of Geography and State Climatologist of Ohio, and Michael Durand, Ph.D., professor, School of Earth Sciences, present on the changing cryosphere in Earth's water cycle\n\nKim Channell, climatologist, Great Lakes Integrated Sciences and Assessments presents Climate Change in the Great Lakes \n\nRobyn Wilson, Ph.D., professor, SENR, presents Communicating climate change and promoting action in the Great Lakes\n\nAudience Q & A with Dr. Durand, Ms. Channell, and Dr. Wilson\n\nConcluding remarks by Jeff Sharp, Ph.D., director, School of Environment and Natural Resources, and Karina Peggau, education and outreach program coordinator, Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center", "channelId": "UCIbosebk4Rh4LLEMKH_Q4Uw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "229", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2H2M2S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.003", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.003", "items": [{"id": "r0wF82eLotk", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-03-05T20:49:44Z", "description": "A. Khalaf, M. Sybeldon, E. Sejdi\u0107, M. Akcakaya, \u201cA brain-computer interface based on functional transcranial Doppler ultrasound using wavelet transform and support vector machines,\u201d Journal of Neuroscience Methods, vol. 293, pp. 174-182, Jan. 2018.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.jneumeth.2017.10.003\n\n\n\nABSTRACT:\n\nBACKGROUND: Functional transcranial Doppler (fTCD) is an ultrasound based neuroimaging technique used to assess neural activation that occurs during a cognitive task through measuring velocity of cerebral blood flow. NEW METHOD: The objective of this paper is to investigate the feasibility of a 2-class and 3-class real-time BCI based on blood flow velocity in left and right middle cerebral arteries in response to mental rotation and word generation tasks. Statistical features based on a five-level wavelet decomposition were extracted from the fTCD signals. The Wilcoxon test and support vector machines (SVM), with a linear kernel, were employed for feature reduction and classification. RESULTS: The experimental results showed that within approximately 3s of the onset of the cognitive task average accuracies of 80.29%, and 82.35% were obtained for the mental rotation versus resting state and the word generation versus resting state respectively. The mental rotation task versus word generation task achieved an average accuracy of 79.72% within 2.24s from the onset of the cognitive task. Furthermore, an average accuracy of 65.27% was obtained for the 3-class problem within 4.68s. COMPARISON WITH EXISTING METHODS: The results presented here provide significant improvement compared to the relevant fTCD-based systems presented in literature in terms of accuracy and speed. Specifically, the reported speed in this manuscript is at least 12 and 2.5 times faster than any existing binary and 3-class fTCD-based BCIs, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: These results show fTCD as a promising and viable candidate to be used towards developing a real-time BCI.\n\n\n#brain #datascience #machinelearning #supportvectormachines #neuroscience #braincomputerinterface #doppler #sonography", "channelTitle": "Ervin Sejdic", "channelId": "UCZTmNHUz63iphbhJc6d__JA", "title": "A brain-computer interface based on transcranial Doppler using support vector machines"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "9", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M51S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.11.001", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.11.001", "items": [{"id": "iJ2jDPgvbTY", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "SciShow", "tags": ["SciShow", "science", "Hank", "Green", "education", "learn", "bats", "zoonotic disease", "mitochondria", "reactive oxygen species", "immune system", "antioxidants", "oxidative stress", "viruses", "inflammation", "acute inflammatory response", "STING proteins", "PYHIN proteins", "disease reservoir", "filoviruses", "henipaviruses", "coronaviruses", "interferon production systems", "dna damage", "interferon alpha", "ribonuclease L", "cytokine storm", "White Nose Syndrome"], "title": "Why Do Bats Carry So Many Dangerous Diseases?", "publishedAt": "2020-03-25T23:17:40Z", "description": "Bats are amazing and not just because they're the only mammal that can fly! Obstetrics and Gynecology, 2013;121(5):1075\u201382\n\nThe Acessa ProVu system is cleared by the FDA for the treatment of symptomatic uterine fibroids under laparoscopic ultrasound guidance. \nThe Acessa procedure is generally safe but complications may occur and can be serious. Risks and complications associated with the Acessa procedure include, but are not limited to: skin burns from the dispersion of radiofrequency energy, mild intra\u2010operative bleeding, transient urinary retention or urinary tract infection, adhesion formation, post\u2010procedural discomfort (cramping, pelvic pain), and transient amenorrhea, infection, injury to adjacent structures, vaginal bleeding and temporary anemia, blood loss requiring transfusion or hysterectomy, pneumothorax, wound dehiscence, deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus, treatment failure, and complications related to laparoscopy and/or general anaesthesia including death. \nInsufficient data exists on which to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of Acessa procedure in women who plan future pregnancy. Therefore, the Acessa procedure is not recommended for women who are planning future pregnancy. There is limited data regarding pregnancy following the Acessa procedure, if you become pregnant following the Acessa procedure, you should contact your doctor immediately. \nPlease consult with your doctor to understand the risks and benefits of surgery and find out if Acessa may be right for you. Rx Only.  \nwww.acessaprocedure.com", "channelId": "UCBh_gqF_nJeq0U_F5_Qh_5Q"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "viewCount": "204", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M15S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.07.007", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.07.007", "items": [{"id": "8p5NyiQgBNY", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-08-13T18:12:12Z", "description": "Michael A. Huffman is a tenured Associate Professor in the Department of Ecology and Social Behavior at the Primate Research Institute, Kyoto University.  In addition to investigations on Japanese macaques spanning 40+ years, he has extensively studied the behavioral ecology of wild chimpanzees in Tanzania and Uganda, with a focus on host-parasite ecology, zoonotic transmission, self-medication, and ethnopharmacology.  He has a special interest in traditional medicines acquired from observations of wild animals for the control of parasitoses and related diseases.  With students and collaborators, he has published on over 15 primate species from apes to lemurs, and other mammal species in Japan, Taiwan, Sri Lanka, India, Vietnam, Bangladesh, China, Thailand, Tanzania, Uganda, South Africa, Madagascar, and Brazil.  He is deeply committed to building bridges through interdisciplinary collaborations and mentoring.", "channelTitle": "Association of Indian Primatologists", "channelId": "UCs3rBANBjDT02PQ7bjS3mcw", "title": "The Evolution of Self-Medication in Primates - Prof. Michael A. Huffman"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "32", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "280", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "liveStreamingDetails": {"actualStartTime": "2020-08-13T04:31:12Z"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H34M27S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.07.007", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.07.007", "items": [{"id": "p4B0mmsaB4o", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "PoRes Communication", "tags": ["poresfi", "tiede", "tutkimus", "mitochondrial disease", "mitochondrial medicine", "mitochondrial myopathy", "mTORC1", "Suomalainen-Wartiovaara", "mitochondria", "myopathy", "ISRmt", "FGF21", "rapamycin", "Deletor", "PEO", "science", "research", "medical"], "title": "New findings on the development of mitochondrial myopathy!", "publishedAt": "2017-08-17T09:07:00Z", "description": "Video production: PoRes Communication\nNarrator: Christopher Carroll, PhD\nAudio recording: Pulu Studio, Helsinki, Finland\n____________________________________________________\n\nProfessor Anu Wartiovaara\u2019s research group from the University of Helsinki has recently published new and significant findings of the development of mitochondrial myopathy. \n\nThis study showed that the activity of mTORC1 complex causes the progression of mitochondrial myopathy through the ISRmt stress response. Rapamycin medication was shown to halt or even improve the hallmarks of the disease by blocking the activity of the mTORC1 complex. The serum secreted FGF21 acts as the ISRmt stress response marker, which can be used to monitor the disease and the treatment.  \n\nOnly a few therapeutic options are currently available for mitochondrial diseases. The research group of Professor Anu Wartiovaara is focused on the understanding of these diseases and on the development of new therapeutic opportunities for the patients. \n\nBased on the findings of this study, the researchers propose that rapamycin therapy studies could be considered for the adult patients with mitochondrial myopathy and elevated FGF21 levels. The promising results presented in this publication bring new hope to the patients and the families affected by this hereditary muscle disease.\n____________________________________________________\n\nOriginal publication:\n\nmTORC1 Regulates Mitochondrial Integrated Stress Response and Mitochondrial Myopathy Progression\n\nKhan, Nikkanen, Yatsuga, Jackson, Wang, Pradhan, Kivel\u00e4, Pessia, Velagapudi & Suomalainen\n\nCell Metabolism 26 (2017) pp. 419-428\nDOI information: 10.1016/j.cmet.2017.07.007\n____________________________________________________ \n\nPoRes Communication \u2013 knowledge from research \u2013 pores.fi", "channelId": "UCkGwH_AA6-dtR_eRIIMNs1w", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "16", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "755", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M31S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.004", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.004", "items": [{"id": "_WuBQ0kD1kM", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2017-12-06T20:46:15Z", "description": "VideoGIE proudly presents the latest installment of the Meet the Masters series, featuring an interview with a legend in the field of endoscopy, Dr. Joseph Barnett Kirsner. \n\nThis open access video and accompanying text can be found here-\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.vgie.2017.10.004", "channelTitle": "VideoGIE Journal", "channelId": "UCin0lnZJW9mHl1kq7kH0nZg", "title": "Kirsner"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "90", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT34M9S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.004", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.10.004", "items": [{"id": "oSsqJkxJi1k", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "MPFNeuro", "defaultLanguage": "en", "title": "Making CRISPR Cas9 work in the brain", "publishedAt": "2017-10-19T19:00:18Z", "description": "Jun Nishiyama*, Takayasu Mikuni*, and Ryohei Yasuda\nNeuron. "2018-02-11T06:24:50Z", "description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\n\nPredicting the next decade of tourism gender research\nAnnette Pritchard\n\nAbstract: This article is an opinion piece, which briefly reviews the ways in which tourism is a hugely important sector for women's employment and entrepreneurship opportunities and ultimately for their life, leisure and business experiences. Its main purpose is to speculate on the future of tourism gender research and practice over the next decade. It suggests that, despite a maturing of the field, research utilising qualitative and feminist methods of inquiry continues to struggle for legitimacy in a field dominated by (post)scientific paradigms and approaches. The piece describes the role senior academics must play to shape a vibrant future for gender studies, through mentoring and by holding knowledge structures and hierarchies to account. The piece concludes by highlighting two areas in which tourism gender scholars could lead research on gendered human experiences in the next decade, namely AI and robotics and sexual exploitation and harassment.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.014", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Predicting the next decade of tourism gender research (Annette Pritchard, 2018)"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "142", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M41S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.future.2017.11.002", "q": "10.1016/j.future.2017.11.002", "items": [{"id": "me2iYK25SyI", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "ACM SIGCHI", "tags": ["SIGCHI", "HRI 2020", "educational technology", "diy", "study at night", "robot kit", "life style", "social robot", "3d printing"], "title": "Flumzis: A DIY robot that improves student performance during study nights", "publishedAt": "2020-04-15T19:00:39Z", "description": "Flumzis: A DIY robot that improves student performance during study nights\nSebastian Caballa, Jose Cortazar, Roberto Raez, Midori Sanchez\n\nHRI'20: ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction\nSession: Student Design Competition\n\nAbstract\nFlumzis is a DIY social robot that optimizes the learning process of college students who spend the entirely night studying. Environmental Impact Assessment Review, v. 67, p. 101-108, 2017.\nDispon\u00edvel em: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eiar.2017.09.001\n\nwww.liga.ufop.br", "channelId": "UCvoC4O-itLvvYLrzGNd5o6A"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "83", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "5", "viewCount": "1589", "dislikeCount": "2"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M26S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "items": [{"id": "qstRIJl1-II", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Elsevier Mechanics Journals", "tags": ["Pump drill; Bi-directional rotary insertion; Energy harvesting; Centrifugation; Biomedical needle"], "title": "Slow motion analysis of a pump drill", "publishedAt": "2017-09-26T06:24:25Z", "description": "Authors:\nZi-Long Zhao (a,) Shiwei Zhou (a), Xi-Qiao Feng (b), and Yi Min Xie (a),(c),*\n\n(a) Centre for Innovative Structures and Materials, School of Engineering, RMIT University, Melbourne 3001, Australia\n(b) AML & CNMM, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Tsinghua University,\nBeijing 100084, China\n(c) XIE Archi-Structure Design (Shanghai) Co., Ltd., Shanghai 200092, China\n\nEmail: mike.xie@rmit.edu.au\n\nhttp://www.journals.elsevier.com/extreme-mechanics-letters/\nDOI: 10.1016/j.eml.2017.09.001", "channelId": "UCy3DUSeIpFox_KaHggQkTNg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "69", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT17S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "items": [{"id": "l-Hx4JyO9iY", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "EnergyScitechCom", "tags": ["Albert Einstein College Of Medicine", "Biochemistry", "Cancer", "Health", "Medicine", "Inforevolution", "Arpacolanews", "OCTOBER 9", "2017"], "title": "New Treatment Causes Cancer to Self Destruct - scitechdaily.com", "publishedAt": "2017-10-10T18:11:32Z", "description": "This image depicts the structure of the BAX protein (purple). The activator compound BTSA1 (orange) has bound to the active site of BAX (green), changing the shape of the BAX molecule at several points (shown in yellow, magenta and cyan). BAX, once in its final activated form, can home in on mitochondria and puncture their outer membranes, triggering apoptosis (cell death). Credit: Albert Einstein College of Medicine\n\nA team of researchers at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine reveals the first compound that directly makes cancer cells commit suicide while sparing healthy cells. The new treatment approach was directed against acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells but may also have potential for attacking other types of cancers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hopeful that the targeted compounds we\u2019re developing will prove more effective than current anti-cancer therapies by directly causing cancer cells to self-destruct,\u201d says Evripidis Gavathiotis, Ph.D., associate professor of biochemistry and of medicine and senior author of the study. \u201cIdeally, our compounds would be combined with other treatments to kill cancer cells faster and more efficiently\u2013and with fewer adverse effects, which are an all-too-common problem with standard chemotherapies.\u201d\n\nAML accounts for nearly one-third of all new leukemia cases and kills more than 10,000 Americans each year. The survival rate for patients has remained at about 30 percent for several decades, so better treatments are urgently needed.\n\nThe newly discovered compound combats cancer by triggering apoptosis\u2013an important process that rids the body of unwanted or malfunctioning cells. Apoptosis trims excess tissue during embryonic development, for example, and some chemotherapy drugs indirectly induce apoptosis by damaging DNA in cancer cells.\n\nApoptosis occurs when BAX\u2013the \u201cexecutioner protein\u201d in cells\u2013is activated by \u201cpro-apoptotic\u201d proteins in the cell. Once activated, BAX molecules home in on and punch lethal holes in mitochondria, the parts of cells that produce energy. But all too often, cancer cells manage to prevent BAX from killing them. They ensure their survival by producing copious amounts of \u201canti-apoptotic\u201d proteins that suppress BAX and the proteins that activate it.\n\n\u201cOur novel compound revives suppressed BAX molecules in cancer cells by binding with high affinity to BAX\u2019s activation site,\u201d says Dr. Gavathiotis. \u201cBAX can then swing into action, killing cancer cells while leaving healthy cells unscathed.\u201d\n\nDr. Gavathiotis was the lead author of a 2008 paper in Nature that first described the structure and shape of BAX\u2019s activation site. He has since looked for small molecules that can activate BAX strongly enough to overcome cancer cells\u2019 resistance to apoptosis. His team initially used computers to screen more than one million compounds to reveal those with BAX-binding potential. The most promising 500 compounds\u2013many of them newly synthesized by Dr. Gavathiotis\u2019 team\u2013were then evaluated in the laboratory.\n\n\u201cA compound dubbed BTSA1 (short for BAX Trigger Site Activator 1) proved to be the most potent BAX activator, causing rapid and extensive apoptosis when added to several different human AML cell lines,\u201d says lead author Denis Reyna, M.S., a doctoral student in Dr. Gavathiotis\u2019 lab. The researchers next tested BTSA1 in blood samples from patients with high-risk AML. Strikingly, BTSA1 induced apoptosis in the patients\u2019 AML cells but did not affect patients\u2019 healthy blood-forming stem cells.\n\nFinally, the researchers generated animal models of AML by grafting human AML cells into mice. BTSA1 was given to half the AML mice while the other half served as controls. On average, the BTSA1-treated mice survived significantly longer (55 days) than the control mice (40 days), with 43 percent of BTSA1-treated AML mice alive after 60 days and showing no signs of AML.\n\nImportantly, the mice treated with BTSA1 showed no evidence of toxicity. \u201cBTSA1 activates BAX and causes apoptosis in AML cells while sparing healthy cells and tissues\u2013probably because the cancer cells are primed for apoptosis,\u201d says Dr. Gavathiotis. He notes that his study found that AML cells from patients contained significantly higher BAX levels compared with normal blood cells from healthy people. \u201cWith more BAX available in AML cells,\u201d he explained, \u201ceven low BTSA1 doses will trigger enough BAX activation to cause apoptotic death, while sparing healthy cells that contain low levels of BAX or none at all.\u201d\n\nPlans call for Dr. Gavathiotis and his team to see whether BTSA1 will show similar effectiveness when tested on animal models of other types of cancer.\n\nPublication: Denis E. Reyna, et al., \u201cDirect Activation of BAX by BTSA1 Overcomes Apoptosis Resistance in Acute Myeloid Leukemia,\u201d Cancer Cell, 2017; doi:10.1016/j.ccell.2017.09.001\n\nSource: Albert Einstein College of Medicine\n\nSite: https://scitechdaily.com/researchers-discover-a-new-compound-that-makes-cancer-cells-self-destruct/", "channelId": "UCSjmhIUju8bG4uWznPpHqCw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "viewCount": "149", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M10S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.001", "items": [{"id": "rQFR4X5hgrU", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Flavonoide", "tags": ["canabidiol", "ciencia", "evidencia", "flavonoide", "\u00f3leo de cbd", "cbd", "cannabis", "maconha", "epilepsia", "cancer", "ansiedade", "depress\u00e3o", "emagrece", "skincare", "mito", "fake news", "antibi\u00f3tico", "inflama\u00e7\u00e3o", "stress oxidativo", "revis\u00e3o", "farm\u00e1cia"], "title": "\u00d3LEO DE CANABIDIOL: o que a ci\u00eancia (realmente) diz sobre 8 usos \"populares\"?", "publishedAt": "2020-02-07T16:00:20Z", "description": "ATEN\u00c7\u00c3O: Esse v\u00eddeo foi feito em cima de uma pesquisa pessoal pelas bases de busca PubMed, Web of Science, Science Direct e SciELO.org. \u00c9 preciso que fique claro que voc\u00ea, ser humano com livre arb\u00edtrio, pode fazer o uso de qualquer coisa do jeito que bem entender, POR\u00c9M n\u00f3s profissionais de sa\u00fade s\u00f3 devemos indicar ou recomendar qualquer coisa com, pelo menos, um m\u00ednimo aceit\u00e1vel de evid\u00eancia cient\u00edfica. Through a systematic review, we analyze and organize the content of 87 academic articles according to the type of involvement of women in family business, i.e. entrepreneurial entry, succession, career dynamics, and presence in family firms. We identify the drivers and outcomes of women\u2019s involvement in family firms at the firm, family, and individual level of analysis, as well as the contextual factors that may influence the aforementioned elements. Fundaci\u00f3n Antioque\u00f1a de Infectologia", "publishedAt": "2017-11-22T12:42:29Z", "description": "en colombia siempre apoyando\nEs una entidad sin \u00e1nimo de lucro dirigida a la prestaci\u00f3n de\nservicios de salud, fundada el 01 de octubre del a\u00f1o 2007 por\nun grupo de m\u00e9dicos especialistas, con el fin de dar atenci\u00f3n a\npatolog\u00edas relacionadas con enfermedades infecciosas, en\ndiferentes partes del pa\u00eds.", "channelId": "UCTMr28d4MdC2VjJJTJUyXnw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "30", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT38M20S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.002", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2017.09.002", "items": [{"id": "OaIiyzLs37Y", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "FONOPEDIA FONOAUDIOLOGIA UC TEMUCO", "tags": ["Fonopedia", "Audiologia", "Vestibular"], "title": "17   Evaluacion Vestibular Cl\u00e1sica 2 - Juan Leyton - Fonopedia Audiovestibular", "publishedAt": "2018-10-16T15:43:23Z", "description": "El proyecto Fonopedia de la carrera de Fonoaudiolog\u00eda de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco, perteneciente al Departamento de Procesos Terap\u00e9uticos de la Facultad de Ciencias de la Salud es un proyecto sin fines de lucro que pretende disminuir las barreras de acceso a la Pr\u00e1ctica Basada en la Evidencia en Fonoaudiolog\u00eda, a trav\u00e9s de una aplicaci\u00f3n m\u00f3vil de diagn\u00f3sticos fonoaudiol\u00f3gicos, recomendaciones de evaluaci\u00f3n e intervenci\u00f3n fonoaudiol\u00f3gica basada en la evidencia cient\u00edfica. \nEl equipo del proyecto est\u00e1 conformado por: \nFlgo. Daniel Rodr\u00edguez Marconi. Director del Proyecto\nFlga. Giorgia Abd-del-Kader. Colaboradora\nFlgo. Felipe Henr\u00edquez. Colaborador\nFlga. Lisette Fuentes. Colaboradora\nFlgo Camilo Morales. Colaborador\nFlgo. Pablo Carrasco. Colaborador\nFlga. Claudia Bascu\u00f1\u00e1n. Colaboradora. \n\nEste proyecto fue financiado por la Direcci\u00f3n General de Docencia de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco en un proyecto docente adjudicado en 2016. Los est\u00e1ndares de grabaci\u00f3n y edici\u00f3n fueron otorgados por la Direcci\u00f3n de Tecnolog\u00edas Educativas de la Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Temuco. \nEl proyecto est\u00e1 abierto a nuevas colaboraciones a medida que sea necesario actualizar la evidencia cient\u00edfica existente, por lo que se admiten futuras colaboraciones para seguir potenciando la Fonoaudiolog\u00eda en Iberoam\u00e9rica. It is also vital to structuring research and developing guidelines for cancer treatment. \n\nThe most widely used system is the TNM system. T stands for tumour, and gives an impression of how large, or how locally invasive the primary tumour is.\n\nN stands for node. This refers to the number of lymph nodes close to the tumour that are affected.\n\nM stands for Metastasis. If a tumour has spread and begins to form secondary tumours in other parts of the body it is said to have metastasised. \n\nThe number system (Stage I-IV) integrates information from the TNM system to come up with a simplified score.\nThis video elaborates on TNM staging for a patient with oral squamous cell carcinoma.\n\n\n\n\n\nAn overview of principles of staging and grading cancers. We discuss the reasons for staging and grading, the differences between them, and their use in different body systems.\n\nIn this video you will learn general rules for cancer staging. "HARICOT - cheap and easy fabrication of hydrogel actuators", "publishedAt": "2017-09-12T11:46:04Z", "description": "Full article online (open access): http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235294071730197X \nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.apmt.2017.08.001\n\n\nHARICOT (Hydrogel Actuators as Responsive Instruments for Cheap Open Technology) is an easy and cheap fabrication methodology for hydrogel actuators.\nThe HARICOT method uses cheap commercially available hydrogel beads toys (Orbeez, Jelly Marbles, Water Beads)  and various strain-directing layers.\nThe methodology is versatile in terms of mixed materials actuators as well as in terms of actuator movements, from bending to spiraling to muscle-like movements.\n\nvideos Quali sono gli errori comuni? \nNon riuscire a toccarsi le punte dei piedi \u00e8 veramente un problema o esistono numerosi fattori da considerare?\n\n\nLe Disfunzioni del Sistema di Movimento si basano sul fatto che i movimenti ripetuti e le posture prolungate causano alterazioni, anche minime, nella precisione del movimento. \nLa diminuita precisione genera microtraumi ai tessuti articolari e periarticolari e, se non interrotta, conduce a macrotraumi e dolore. Questa affermazione \u00e8 alla base del modello kinesiopatologico, in cui il movimento alterato danneggia i tessuti e causa il dolore, e pu\u00f2 meglio interpretare il dolore muscolo-scheletrico di origine non traumatica.\n\nGruppo DSM\n\nsito: www.gruppodsm.it\nFacebook: fb.com/GruppoDSM\n_______________________________________________________________\n\n\nBIBLIOGRAFIA.\n\u201cChapter 3 - Movement Impairment Syndromes of the Lumbar Spine. - Flexion: Forward Bending.\u201d Diagnosis and Treatment of Movement Impairment Syndromes: Includes e-Book, by Shirley Sahrmann, Elsevier Mosby, 2001, pp. 58\u201360.\n\n\u201cChapter 9 - Axial Skeleton: Osteology and Arthrology. -Variations of Lumbopelvic Rhythms during Trunk Flexion from a Standing Position: A Kinematic Analysis.\u201d Kinesiology of the Musculoskeletal System: Foundations for Rehabilitation, by Donald A. "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Nutrition Made Simple!", "tags": ["nutrition", "plant-based", "vegan", "vegetarian", "healthy diet", "high cholesterol", "cholesterol foods", "Saturated vs unsaturated fat", "Saturated fat", "Saturated fat foods", "unsaturated fat", "Saturated vs unsaturated fats", "Saturated fat cholesterol", "Saturated fat unhealthy", "Is Saturated fat bad", "Is Saturated fat good", "Saturated fat vs unsaturated fat", "Saturated fat heart disease", "unsaturated fat foods", "Is Saturated fat good for you", "Saturated fat keto", "Saturated fat high cholesterol"], "title": "Saturated vs Unsaturated Fat | Eat or Avoid?", "publishedAt": "2020-06-15T13:00:01Z", "description": "Saturated vs Unsaturated fat, which is better? Are saturated fat foods healthy or harmful? The science on saturated vs unsaturated fat foods, the controversies and the exceptions.\n\nSubscribe for more free nutrition and health tips: https://bit.ly/2toMJ9u\n\nConnect with me:\nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/DrGilCarvalho/\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/NutritionMadeS3\nAnimations: Even Topland @toplandmedia\n\nSaturated vs unsaturated fat, let's make sense of fats!\n\nSaturated fat is concentrated in animal foods and some plant products like coconut oil while Unsaturated fat is concentrated in plants.\n\nSaturated fat raises cholesterol levels. But does it cause heart disease?\nClassical studies linked saturated fat and heart disease, so saturated fat was widely seen as a problem until a media storm a few years ago. Was saturated fat fine after all? \n\nIn 2 studies, people eating less saturated fat had just as much cardiovascular disease. So maybe saturated fat is not a factor?\n\nHarvard study: People who eat less saturated fat and more unsaturated fat instead have lower risk. Those who eat more whole grains instead also had lower risk. But refined grains were no better than saturated fat.\n\nBut maybe they eat less saturated fat, less cheese and meat and also smoke less and exercise more. How do we know the saturated fat has anything to do with them being healthier? A brand new study found people told to eat less  saturated fat have less cardiovascular disease. It wasn\u2019t clear which food replacements were best but less  saturated fat led to less risk. They found no harmful effects of reducing saturated fat.\nSaturated fat always raises emotions. I used to eat a lot more saturated fat and gradually adapted. Others might make a different decision.\n\nThis means favoring unprocessed plant foods which are low in saturated vs unsaturated fats. Fish is also a wise choice due to the balance of saturated vs unsaturated fat. Some types of saturated fat are worse than others. We covered dietary patterns low in saturated fat and high in unsaturated fats in previous videos.\n\nReferences:\nsaturated fat and serum cholesterol levels: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2125600/\nAHA Advisory: https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000510\n2 studies that generated the media storm:\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24723079/\nhttps://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20071648/\nHarvard study:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4593072/\nrecent randomized trial (Cochrane): www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD011737.pub2/full\nstearic acid doesn't raise LDL-c: https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/77/5/1146/4689813\nchocolate and risk:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S089990071730206X\nhttps://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/9/7/688\n\nDisclaimer: The contents of this video are for informational purposes only and are not intended to be medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment, nor to replace medical care. The information presented herein is accurate and conforms to the available scientific evidence to the best of the author's knowledge as of the time of posting. Brains", "publishedAt": "2017-12-06T17:09:45Z", "description": "Thanks to 23andMe for sponsoring this video! http://www.23andme.com/minuteearth\nIf you live outside the US, click here: https://www.23andme.com/\n\nWhen we domesticate an animal species, their brains shrink and they freak out less.\n\nThanks also to our supporters on https://www.patreon.com/MinuteEarth\n\nAnd to our SPONSORS on YouTube.\n___________________________________________\n\nTo learn more, start your googling with these keywords: \nDomesticated animal: a species of animal bred by humans over generations to become nonreactive and gain characteristics suitable for life as a farm animal or pet\n\nTame animal: an individual animal raised in a way that it has become less dangerous and frightened of people\n\nFeral animal: an animal that escapes from captivity or domestication (& regains some similar & some different characteristics compared to its pre-domesticated state)\n\n\"Fight or flight\": an instinctive physiological response to a threatening situation that readies a creature to either to resist forcibly or escape\n\nLimbic system: the brain\u2019s \u201cpanic button\u201d - a system of nerves and networks near the bottom of the cortex that controls basic emotions (e.g. fear, pleasure, anger) and drives (e.g. hunger, sex, dominance)\n\nTelencephalon: the most developed and anterior part of the forebrain, consisting chiefly of the cerebral hemispheres, and the brain region that shrinks most in domesticated animals\n\nDomestication: a sustained multigenerational, mutualistic relationship in which one species (e.g. humans) assumes a significant degree of influence over the reproduction and care of another species (e.g. cows) in order to secure a more predictable supply of a resource of interest (e.g. milk/meat/traction), and through which the domesticated organisms gain advantage over individuals that remain outside this relationship (e.g. aurochs, which went extinct), thereby benefitting and often increasing the fitness of both species involved\n___________________________________________\n\nIf you liked this week\u2019s video, you "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Manifold", "tags": ["The 1619 Project", "James Oakes", "City University of New York", "Slavery", "Thomas Jefferson", "Founding Fathers", "History"], "title": "James Oakes on What\u2019s Wrong with The 1619 Project - #46", "publishedAt": "2020-05-14T11:00:27Z", "description": "Steve and Corey talk to James Oakes, Distinguished Professor of History and Graduate School Humanities Professor at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, about \"The 1619 Project\" developed by The New York Times Magazine. The project argues that slavery was the defining event of US history. Jim argues that slavery was actually the least exceptional feature of the US and that what makes the US exceptional is that it is where abolition first begins. Steve wonders about the views of Thomas Jefferson who wrote that \u201call men are created equal\u201d but still held slaves. Jim maintains many founders were hypocrites, but Jefferson believed what he wrote.\n \nTopics: Northern power, Industrialization, Capitalism, Lincoln, Inequality, Cotton, Labor, Civil War, Racism/Antiracism, Black Ownership. \n\nTranscript\nhttps://manifoldlearning.com/episode-046#transcript\n\nJames Oakes (Bio)\nhttps://www.gc.cuny.edu/Faculty/Core-Bios/James-Oakes \n\nOakes and Colleagues Letter to the NYT and the Editor\u2019s Response\nhttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/20/magazine/we-respond-to-the-historians-who-critiqued-the-1619-project.html\n\nThe Fight Over the 1619 Project Is Not About the Facts\nhttps://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2019/12/historians-clash-1619-project/604093/\n\nThe World Socialist Web Site interview with James Oakes \nhttps://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2019/11/18/oake-n18.html \n\nBenjamin Lay, the first revolutionary abolitionist\nhttps://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/quaker-comet-greatest-abolitionist-never-heard-180964401/\n\nOakes, J. Join them for wide ranging and unfiltered conversations with leading writers, scientists, technologists, academics, entrepreneurs, investors, and more.\n\nSteve Hsu is VP for Research and Professor of Theoretical Physics at Michigan State University. He is also a researcher in computational genomics and founder of several Silicon Valley startups, ranging from information security to biotech. Educated at Caltech and Berkeley, he was a Harvard Junior Fellow and held faculty positions at Yale and the University of Oregon before joining MSU.\n\nCorey Washington is Director of Analytics in the Office of Research and Innovation at Michigan State University. He was educated at Amherst College and MIT before receiving a PhD in Philosophy from Stanford and a PhD in a Neuroscience from Columbia. He held faculty positions at the University Washington and the University of Maryland. University", "Demystifying Medicine", "Lyme disease", "Ticks", "Deer tick", "ixodes scapularis", "black-legged tick", "infectious disease"], "title": "TICKTALK: Ticks and Lyme disease", "publishedAt": "2019-03-02T22:06:56Z", "description": "Lyme disease is becoming a national threat to both human and animal health in Ontario and North America. This video hopes to bring attention to the severity of this issue. Warming temperatures as a result of climate change are causing tick populations to sky-rocket and with more ticks comes more disease. Specifically, the increase in black-legged tick/deer tick (ixodes scapularis) population results in the increased prevalence of Lyme disease. This video not only aims to raise awareness but also outlines what people can do to protect themselves and their families.\n\nThis video was made by McMaster Demystifying Medicine students (Niharika Verma, Ray Husain, Harshil Chudasama & Smyrna Gudagunti) \n\nCopyright McMaster University 2019\n\nReferences\n\nChrdle, A., Chmel\u00edk, V., & R\u016f\u017eek, D. Wsp\u00f3lnymi si\u0142ami ufundowali\u015bmy ju\u017c prawie 200 tys. posi\u0142k\u00f3w! Bardzo Wam za to dzi\u0119kuj\u0119! \n\nSubskrybuj Polimaty 2, o tutaj: http://bit.ly/1sLH059 - a je\u015bli ju\u017c subskrybujesz to kliknij w DZWONECZEK (nie my\u015bla\u0142em, \u017ce kiedykolwiek wypowiem to zdanie).\n\nOdradzam obserwowanie mojego konta na Instagramie http://instagram.com/radekkotarski bo du\u017co przyjemniejsze jest prze\u017cywanie w\u0142asnego \u017cycia ni\u017c ogl\u0105danie \u017cycia i rzyci innych ludzi. Na Facebooku te\u017c nie znajdziecie szczeg\u00f3lnie du\u017co. Ot, tablica og\u0142osze\u0144 parafialnych r\u00f3wnie ciekawa, co w Twojej okolicznej parafii. \n\nKto stoi za tym programem? "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.006", "items": [{"id": "0D2jrg6Ngpo", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en-GB", "channelTitle": "Data-driven", "tags": ["risk aversion", "risk", "children", "babies", "baby", "gender", "female", "daughter", "parents", "research", "study", "behaviour", "pregnancy", "risk attitudes", "child gender", "Trivers-Willard hypothesis", "gender inequalities"], "title": "Female Babies and Risk-Aversion: Causal evidence from hospital wards", "publishedAt": "2018-07-31T02:41:57Z", "description": "Using ultrasound scan data from paediatric hospitals, and the exogenous \u2018shock\u2019 of learning the gender of an unborn baby, the paper documents the first causal evidence that offspring gender affects adult risk-aversion. On a standard Holt-Laury criterion, parents of daughters, whether unborn or recently born, become almost twice as risk-averse as parents of sons. The study demonstrates this in longitudinal and cross-sectional data, for fathers and mothers, for babies in the womb and new-born children, and in a West European nation and East European nation. These findings may eventually aid our understanding of risky health behaviors and gender inequalities.\n\nReference:\nPogrebna, G., Oswald, A. J., and Haig, D. (2018) \"Female babies and risk-aversion: Causal evidence from hospital wards\" Journal of Health Economics, (58), pp. 10\u201317. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhealeco.2017.12.006\n\nFull paper (Open Access): https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167629617304538", "channelId": "UC7QY4zs_ASJej2CvQTGikhg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "5", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "138", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M45S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.006", "items": [{"id": "ulu8DLS3tUg", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Australian Research Data Commons - ARDC", "tags": ["open-science", "big-data", "escience", "data-deluge", "ands-data", "data-management", "ands", "research", "data", "university", "funding", "management", "research-data", "mobile data collection", "feild data collection", "field work", "FAIMS"], "title": "FAIMS Mobile: Customisable Electronic Field Notebooks - Webinar", "publishedAt": "2019-09-16T03:07:52Z", "description": "Recorded 5 Sep 2019.\nA/Prof Shawn Ross and Dr Brian Ballsun-Stanton, Macquarie University\n\nFAIMS Mobile is a generalised, customisable electronic notebook for field data collection in offline or network-degraded settings. Funded by ARC, NeCTAR, and NSW grants, it is open-source and community-driven software, developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems (FAIMS) project.\n\nUnlike other systems, FAIMS Mobile was designed from the beginning to support transparency, reproducibility, and data sharing in field-research domains that involve complex and diverse workflows, data models, and automation / verification requirements. Since its first production release in late 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been deployed for over 50 workflows at more than 30 projects in archaeology, geoscience, ecology, ethnography, oral history, and linguistics. Experience from these deployments has been fed back into the \u2018core\u2019 platform , and has produced a growing library of openly licensed, reusable customisation files on GitHub.\n\nFAIMS Mobile has a unique combination of features supporting field data capture, including:\n\n- Data and interface customisation, allowing modification and re-deployment by users.\n- Collection of various data types within a single record, including structured data, geospatial data, free text, sensor-produced data, and file attachments.\n- Multimedia management; image, sound, and video files can be automatically renamed based on data in associated records, and that data can be written to multimedia metadata.\n- An append-only datastore allows users to review and reverse changes to records selectively.\n- Unlimited devices can create, edit, and view records to sync \u2018eventually\u2019 without data loss.\n- Defaults, flow logic, hierarchical vocabularies, validation, and other data collection features.\n- Mobile GIS supporting raster and vector data, layer management, legacy data visualisation, and point, line, and polygon creation and editing.\n- Internal and external sensor and peripheral support.\n- Multilingual support using a localisation file.\n- \u2018Annotation\u2019 and \u2018certainty\u2019 support marginal notes and confidence indication for records.\n- Aids to good practice including contextual HTML help, selections based on images, and selection trees that can guide users through complex processes.\n- Embedding of URIs into controlled vocabularies or other elements to link them to shared vocabularies, thesauri, or ontologies.\n- Generation / application of globally unique persistent identifiers in the field (e.g., IGSNs).\n- Customisable export to desktop software, pre-existing databases, or online data services.\n\nTaken together, these features support the production of consistent, comprehensive datasets that are well-documented and analysis-ready upon export, and facilitate the creation of FAIR data.\nThis webinar will provide an introduction to FAIMS Mobile features, architecture, and use cases. We will also talk about the future of FAIMS, possible directions for development, and opportunities for collaboration.\n\nFor more information, see:\nBallsun-Stanton, B., Ross, S. A., Sobotkova, A., & Crook, P. (2018). FAIMS Mobile: Flexible, open-source software for field research. SoftwareX, 7C, 47\u201352. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.softx.2017.12.006\n\n\n\n\n\nSlides etc available from: https://github.com/FAIMS", "channelId": "UClbZWqIv8Si0siuizaxAS1A", "defaultLanguage": "en-GB"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "66", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT52M57S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.006", "items": [{"id": "QP6TfYF1ELU", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2018-11-23T03:20:32Z", "description": "PSYO 317 -  Final Project \n\nBy: Isadora Kuipers \n\nReferences: \n\nDuncker, K. Neste v\u00eddeo fazemos outra sequ\u00eancia de movimentos de ch\u00e3o para integra\u00e7\u00e3o do quadril. Mas ela vai muito al\u00e9m disso. \n\n\n\nEsta sequ\u00eancia de movimentos contribui para o alinhamento da coluna vertebral, alonga a musculatura das duas cinturas: p\u00e9lvica e escapular, e ainda fortalece a musculatura dos membros inferiores.\n\n\nIsso mesmo, sua base estrutural vem de uma postura do ioga chamada  Ananda Bal\u00e1sana, que em s\u00e2nscrito significa postura do beb\u00ea feliz.\n\nVamos fazer a sequ\u00eancia?\n\nSe voc\u00ea gostou desse conte\u00fado, curta, comente o que achou, e compartilhe para levarmos a informa\u00e7\u00e3o para mais pessoas! Open Science, 5(9), 181295.\nhttp://rsos.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/5/9/181295\n______________________________________________\n\nVis\u00edtanos tambi\u00e9n en:\n\nEl blog:\nhttp://palaeos-blog.blogspot.com\n\nLa p\u00e1gina de Facebook:\nhttps://www.facebook.com/PalaeosPag\n\nEl instagram:\nhttps://www.instagram.com/palaeoshvt/", "channelId": "UCkr852ARAIM8Lg4ahtQwtRA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "889", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "48", "viewCount": "12109", "dislikeCount": "5"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT8M36S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.010", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2017.12.010", "items": [{"id": "3Sdiz8S9EKI", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "bn", "channelTitle": "Keno", "tags": ["bcg vaccine", "bcg vaccine use", "bcg vaccine coronavirus", "bcg vaccine in india", "bcg vaccine for covid 19", "bcg vaccine full form", "bcg vaccine route", "bcg vaccine coronavirus india", "bcg vaccine age", "bcg vaccine mark", "bcg vaccine scar", "iiser kolkata", "Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Kolkata"], "title": "BCG (Bacillus Calmette\u2013Gu\u00e9rin) Vaccine \u0995\u09bf \u09b8\u09a4\u09cd\u09af\u09bf CoronaVirus (COVID-19) \u09b0\u09cb\u0997\u09c7\u09b0 \u098f\u0995\u09ae\u09be\u09a4\u09cd\u09b0 \u099a\u09bf\u0995\u09bf\u09ce\u09b8\u09be ?", "publishedAt": "2020-04-14T03:30:00Z", "description": "BCG (Bacillus Calmette\u2013Gu\u00e9rin) Vaccine \u0995\u09bf \u09b8\u09a4\u09cd\u09af\u09bf CoronaVirus (COVID-19) \u09b0\u09cb\u0997\u09c7\u09b0 \u098f\u0995\u09ae\u09be\u09a4\u09cd\u09b0 \u099a\u09bf\u0995\u09bf\u09ce\u09b8\u09be ?\n\nThere is no evidence that the Bacille Calmette-Gu\u00e9rin vaccine (BCG) protects people against infection with the COVID-19 virus. Two clinical trials addressing this question are underway, and the WHO will evaluate the evidence when it is available. In the absence of evidence, the WHO does not recommend BCG vaccination for the prevention of COVID-19. WHO continues to recommend neonatal BCG vaccination in countries or settings with a high incidence of tuberculosis.\n\nThere is experimental evidence from both animal and human studies that the BCG vaccine has non-specific effects on the immune system. These effects have not been well characterized and their clinical relevance is unknown.\n\nOn 11 April 2020, WHO updated its ongoing evidence review of the major scientific databases and clinical trial repositories, using English, French and Chinese search terms for COVID-19, coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2 and BCG.\n\nThe review yielded three preprints (manuscripts posted online before peer-review), in which the authors compared the incidence of COVID-19 cases in countries where the BCG vaccine is used with countries where it is not used and observed that countries that routinely used the vaccine in neonates had less reported cases of COVID-19 to date. Such ecological studies are prone to significant bias from many confounders, including differences in national demographics and disease burden, testing rates for COVID-19 virus infections, and the stage of the pandemic in each country. \n\nThe review also yielded two registered protocols for clinical trials, both of which aim to study the effects of BCG vaccination given to health care workers directly involved in the care of patients with COVID-19.\n\nBCG vaccination prevents severe forms of tuberculosis in children and diversion of local supplies may result in neonates not being vaccinated, resulting in an increase of disease and deaths from tuberculosis. In the absence of evidence, the WHO does not recommend BCG vaccination for the prevention of COVID-19. WHO continues to recommend neonatal BCG vaccination in countries or settings with a high incidence of tuberculosis.\n\nReferences\n\n    BCG vaccines: WHO position paper \u2013 February 2018. Vaccins BCG: Note de synth\u00e8se de l\u2019OMS \u2013 F\u00e9vrier 2018. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2018;93(8):73\u201396. Published 2018 Feb 23.\n     de Bree LCJ, Marijnissen RJ, Kel JM, et al. Bacillus Calmette-Gu\u00e9rin-Induced Trained Immunity Is Not Protective for Experimental Influenza A/Anhui/1/2013 (H7N9) Infection in Mice [published correction appears in Front Immunol. 2018 Oct 25;9:2471]. Front Immunol. 2018;9:869. Published 2018 Apr 30. doi:10.3389/fimmu.2018.00869.\n    Arts RJW, Moorlag SJCFM, Novakovic B, et al. BCG Vaccination Protects against Experimental Viral Infection in Humans through the Induction of Cytokines Associated with Trained Immunity. Cell Host Microbe. 2018;23(1):89\u2013100.e5. doi:10.1016/j.chom.2017.12.010.\n     Reducing Health Care Workers Absenteeism in Covid-19 Pandemic Through BCG Vaccine (BCG-CORONA). https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT04328441.\n    BCG Vaccination to Protect Healthcare Workers Against COVID-19 (BRACE). https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT04327206.\n    Cernuschi T, Malvolti S, Nickels E, Friede M. Bacillus Calmette-Gu\u00e9rin (BCG) vaccine: A global assessment of demand and supply balance.
