(2018) Mitochondrial Transfer: The making of three-parent babies. recuperado de: http://sitn.hms.harvard.edu/flash/2018/mitochondrial-transfer-making-three-parent-babies/", "channelTitle": "Nely Pineda", "channelId": "UCdehkdDBzPOXhLX9Rzi_iaw", "title": "\u00bfBeb\u00e9s de 3 ADN? \u00bfEs \u00e9tico?"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "3", "viewCount": "13", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT10M3S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "items": [{"id": "ZFz2MLyaOjk", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Otolaryngologist,ORL,ENT-Medical Office,Artz Praxis", "tags": ["The", "sensorineural", "hearing", "loss", "(SNHL)", "in", "Chronic", "suppurative", "otitis", "media", "(CSOM)"], "title": "The sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)", "publishedAt": "2018-01-08T13:09:09Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRisk factors of sensorineural hearing loss in patients with unilateral safe chronic suppurative otitis media\r\nAbd Elrheem Ahmed Singer, Osama G. Abdel-Naby Awad'Correspondence information about the author Osama G. Abdel-Naby AwadEmail the author Osama G. Abdel-Naby Awad, Rafeek Mohamed Abd El-Kader, Ahmed Rabeh Mohamed\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.amjoto.2018.01.002\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nReferences\r\nAbstract\r\nPurpose\r\nChronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the major cause of hearing impairment, especially conductive hearing loss. Few patients also had sensorineural component, the sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in CSOM is controversial, especially for safe mucosal type. This study aims to assess the relationship between the frequency of SNHL development in patients with safe mucosal CSOM and its relation to patient's age, sex, duration of disease, size of perforation and different audiological findings.\r\n\r\nMaterial and methods\r\nThis is a prospective study conducted from June 2016 to June 2017 in a tertiary referral hospital. 200 patients with unilateral mucosal type of CSOM with normal contralateral ear were included in the study. The diseased ears were taken as study ears and normal ears as control ears in all patients. Detailed otologic history, clinical and audiometric findings were recorded and analyzed. Results were statistically compared in all patients for both study and control ears using different parameters.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nTwenty patients had an average bone conduction threshold of all frequencies above 25\u2005dB, which implies SNHL (10%). The incidence of SNHL was statistically significant at higher speech frequencies. The incidence increased with the presence of Diabetes Mellitus, smoking, duration of disease, presence of active discharge and the increase in size of perforation. However, it is not age dependent and there was no difference between males and females.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nSafe mucosal CSOM can cause SNHL with multiple predisposing factors.\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelId": "UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "66", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M36S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "items": [{"id": "xwrU1_DpK-s", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2019-04-15T11:46:12Z", "description": "", "channelTitle": "Webcasting Now", "channelId": "UChcN_FmYIWMDVG0AriAt3Uw", "title": "Capture0002"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "14", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H5M57S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.002", "items": [{"id": "XUM4EyVU2Js", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Heal to Bliss", "tags": ["#HealtoBliss", "#yoga", "#naturecure", "#healthylifestyle", "#health", "#ayush", "#staysafe", "#stayhealthy", "#positivevibes", "#healthwithbreath", "#bodymindsoul", "#yogainspiration", "#yogaforeveryday", "#yogameditationfitness", "#nature", "#yogajourney", "#peace", "#yogapose", "#selfhealing", "#relaxationtechniques"], "title": "Yoga therapy for Cervical Pain I Dr. Nandini I Heal to Bliss", "publishedAt": "2020-05-30T04:06:01Z", "description": "Welcome to the series of Yoga therapy for various health issues by Dr. Nandini, Yoga & Naturopathy. \n\nPain in the neck and shoulder that varies in intensity and may feel achy or like an electric shock from the neck to the arm. It particularly looks to highlight the operational co-production of heritage and tourism and shows that tourism has never worked better, faster and more efficiently as a heritage-producing machine than in this beginning of the 21st century. We are on the threshold of a new \u201cheritage regime\u201d, which presents a gap compared with the one that produced the major European national heritages in the State-Nations of the 19th century. The tourism system (tourism actors, places and businesses as well as tourists themselves) contribute to the production of a new heritage system (heritage places, practices and actors) which functions according to its own needs and expectations, in a world of free traffic, transactions and generalized mobilities.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2018.01.004\n\n--\n\nMaking sense of heritage tourism: Research trends in a maturing field of study\nDallen Timothy\n\nAbstract: This essay examines several emerging research trends in the field of heritage tourism. These trends, including experiential connections with heritage, blurred boundaries between tourisms, more accurate portrayals of the commodified past and technological advancements, demonstrate a precipitous growth in heritage tourism scholarship that focuses more on experience, identity, stewardship, place and empowerment than the more descriptive supply v. demand work that preceded it. Changes in how researchers treat the cultural past indicate a maturing field of study that is increasing in popularity as a focus of academic research and also as a consumable tourist product.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.018", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Heritage Tourism (Maria Gravari-Barbas / Dallen Timothy, 2018)"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "150", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M13S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "PaneLNKJfEU", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en-GB", "channelTitle": "Science Animated", "tags": ["gamasoidosis", "avian-mite dermatitis", "One Health approach", "Dermatology", "Medical Entomology", "Parasitology", "Lyme disease agents", "ectoparasites", "mites", "mite infestations", "mite bites", "zoonotic mites", "itching", "dermatitis", "papular dermatitis", "pigeons", "synanthropic birds", "pets", "rodents", "Dermanyssus gallinae", "red mite", "Ornithonyssus bacoti", "tropical rat mite"], "title": "Mesostigmatic mite infestation in city-dwellers: diagnosis and control", "publishedAt": "2019-11-04T15:54:51Z", "description": "mariaassunta.cafiero@izspb.it\nMaria Assunta Cafiero, DVM, PhD\nUnit of Medical Entomology (Department of Virology)\n\nIstituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale della Puglia e della Basilicata, \nVia Manfredonia, 20 - Syn-eruptive Rhine damming I\nCornelia Park, Hans-Ulrich Schminck at al 2019\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.jvolgeores.2019.106688\n\nA new look at an old dog: Bonn-Oberkassel reconsidered, Journal of Archaeological Science, Janssens at al 2018, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jas.2018.01.004\n\nAusbreitung der Ahrensburger und Hamburger Kultur nach Mittelengland, D\u00e4nemark und Schweden, derzeit datiert auf rund 9.600 v. Chr.  mit Anzeichen fr\u00fcherer nacheiszeitlicher Aktivit\u00e4ten. Hominide Gene belegen klar die Ausbreitung \u00fcber Doggerland nach England und Schottland sowie \u00fcber die D\u00e4nische Festlandbr\u00fccke nach Scane in Schweden sowie S\u00fcdnorwegen. Die westskandinavien Saamen (z.b. aus Lappland) zeigen daher eine h\u00f6here Abstammung von den Federmessergruppen Mitteleuropas (assoziiert mit Haplogruppe I2a2, Villanova Cluster). Diese waren auch die ersten Besiedler Skandinaviens. Einwanderer \u00fcber Russland sind ab ca. 8000 v. Chr. am Ladoga und Onager See nachweisbar und vermischten sich sp\u00e4ter im Hohen Norden zu den heutigen Saamen. Etwa ab 9000 Chr. wurde diese fr\u00fche  skandinavische Population (Komsa-Hensbakker-Fosna Kultur Complex) durch einen glazialen Kanal vom Kontinent getrennt, durch den die damalige Ostsee (Yoldiameer) \u00fcber den V\u00e4nner See abfloss. Erst nach 7700 v. Chr. entstand der Abfluss \u00fcber den Belt in den Kattegat. Beide J\u00e4ger und Sammler Kulturen trafen erneut aufeinander und es kam zur erneuten Ausbreitung kontinentaler J\u00e4ger und Sammler vom Kontinent aus der sich u.a. die Erteb\u00f6lle Kultur und weitere Ostsee-Kulturen dieser Zeit entwickelte. \nDNA Untersuchtungen an Hunden belegen das alle Nordeurop\u00e4ischen Hunde zum selben Genpool geh\u00f6rten und sich erst fr\u00fchestens in der Bronzezeit mit weiteren eingewanderten Hundepopulationen mischten. Der Hundegenpool war also bis ins sp\u00e4te Neolithikum/fr\u00fche Bronzezeit unbeeinflusst. (basierend auf Cherry Tree Cave, New Grange Dog, Norge Elk Dog, Saami Dogs und Samojeden) die auf die Domestikation eines Nordeurop\u00e4ischen Wolfes beruhen, gefunden in der Goyat-H\u00f6hle in Belgien. Diese Wolfspopulation ist ausgestorben.\nSaamische, Samojedische und Russische Hunde sind sp\u00e4ter in der Bronzezeit mit einer sibirischen Wolfspopulation (nachgewiesen auf der Tamyr Insel) gekreuzt worden. Englische Hunde mit einer eisenzeitlichen Hundepopulation die durch die R\u00f6mer verbreitet wurde und Wolfsgene aus Anatolien oder Asien trugen. \nUnklar ist ob die Domestikation von W\u00f6lfen ein einmaliges Ereignis mit weiterer Kreuzung wilder Wolfspopulationen in verschiedenen Ecken der Welt war wohin Hunde den Menschen folgten oder ob es verschiedene Domestikationen gab. Fraglich ist auch ob es \u00fcberhaupt eine aktive Domestikation gab oder es W\u00f6lfe einfach f\u00fcr bequemer fanden. sich dem Mensch zum Freund zu machen um von ihm Fressen zu bekommen. Paleolithische Untersuchungen zeigen, W\u00f6lfe folgen Menschen schon seit mehr als 50.000 Jahren und zeigen J\u00e4gern auch an, das keine B\u00e4ren in der N\u00e4he sind. Daher profitierten J\u00e4ger auch von der Anwesenheit wilder W\u00f6lf. Sofern sie keine Herde  sch\u00fctzen war der Wolf durchaus ein gern gesehener Nachbar der u.a. auch Nahrungsabf\u00e4lle beseitigte.\n\nDer plinischen Eruption folgten aufgestaute Seen bei Brohl und Koblenz, die f\u00fcr\nmehrere \u00dcberflutungen am darunter ablaufenden Rhein verantwortlich waren.\nIn dieser Studie wurde nur der Lake Brohl untersucht. Die Flutereignisse am Koblenzer See sind nicht beschrieben.\nIm sogenannten Lake Brohl wurden 5 Flutereignisse nachgewiesen,\nFlut unmittelbar nach der Eruption: Wasserstand 4,5 m\nFlut 1: 4m - hier staut sich das Bett des Rhein auf\nFlut 2: 7,5m - nun stauen sich auch die s\u00fcdlichen und n\u00f6rdlichen Arme auf\nFlut 3: 8,5m - das Land zwischen den Armen und dem Bett wird geflutet\nFlut 4: 11m - eine durchgehende Wasserdecke \u00fcber alle Seitenarme\nFlut 5: 12m - die Wasserdecke steigt \u00fcber alle Arme hinaus\ndabei wurden Steine bis zu einer Gr\u00f6\u00dfe einer Garage stromabw\u00e4rts transportiert,\naber auch die gesamte Ufervegetation inkl. dortiger W\u00e4lder die alle stromabw\u00e4rts\nfortgerissen wurden. \nMehrere Sto\u00dffluten mit erheblichem Druck wurden auch am englischen Kanal nachgewiesen wo das Wasser seit 100.000 Jahren den Damm abtrug und auch hier muss ja das Wasser irgendwoher kommen. Die letzte Trennung vom Festland erfolgte wohl im Zusammenhang mit der fortschreitenden Littorina-Transgression (Anhebung Skandinaviens) und Umformung der Ostsee, wodurch auch das Eifel Vulkanfeld aktiv war und derartige Flutevents ausl\u00f6ste, die ausreichten um die endg\u00fcltige Trennung Englands vom Kontinent zu vollenden.", "channelId": "UCvHzpeTXbVL8xJap-4-hR4Q"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "11", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "1466", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M34S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "xRCKAQYAvnc", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "K Lab", "tags": ["#Literaturereview", "#Evidence", "#Evidence-basedtreatment", "#EBP", "#Parents", "#Decisionmaking", "#Earlyintervention", "#Autism", "#Autismmom", "#Autismparents", "#Autismdad", "#ABA", "#BCBA", "#BCABA", "#RBT", "#CalABA2020", "#Twitch", "#WeAreKlab"], "title": "How do parents select evidence-based treatments?", "publishedAt": "2020-06-17T22:14:12Z", "description": "Christina Melanie Saez and Matthew Davies from KLab conducted a literature review that was accepted to the poster panel of CalABA 2020 (canceled). (Neuroscience and Pleasure)", "publishedAt": "2020-04-29T18:00:17Z", "description": "First 200 people to use this link https://brilliant.org/WIL/ can get 20% off an annual premium subscription to Brilliant!\n\n\u25bcNewsletter signup: https://mailchi.mp/a58275fd1906/josepheverettwil\n\u25b2Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/WILearned\n\u25b2Twitter: https://twitter.com/jeverettlearned\n\u25b2IG: https://www.instagram.com/jeverett.whativelearned/\n\nBooks:\nJeffrey Schwartz's \"Brain Lock\" - https://amzn.to/2VP0dKI\nJaak Panksepp's \"Affective Neuroscience\" - https://amzn.to/3f3fv5U\nAnjan Chatterjee's \"The Aesthetic Brain\" - https://amzn.to/3bTQGre\nMihaly Csikszentmihalyi's \"Flow\" - https://amzn.to/2WaIfkH\nGregory Bern's \"Satisfaction!\" - https://amzn.to/2SmmfSL\n\n---\nI actually started out working on this video with the aim to understand why \"oddly satisfying\" videos are satisfying. I figured the first step with that was to figure out why *anything* is satisfying. Since we call a lot of things satisfying, this was harder than I expected. When things are in perfect sync it's satisfying, when things are in perfect order is satisfying, it's satisfying when you are arranging your new living room and then the short square table you have fits perfectly between your two sofas and the surface of the table is flush with both sofa's arm rests. (Fun fact: in Japanese, you just say \"feels good\" (kimochi ii) for things like this) Unsurprisingly, there's not much research on the concept of \"satisfying.\"  \n\nThen I started looking into why we find things pleasurable. Jaak Panksepp says that things that are pleasurable are *biologically useful* . So it was even more curious that things seemingly irrelevant to keeping us alive should make us feel good.  \n\nThis video is the result of cobbling a bit of logic with information from books on Satisfaction, neuroscience, 'what the brain finds beautiful' as well as various research papers on the brain. I hope it's satisfying. \n\n(If editing videos didn't take so gotham long,  this video would be about an hour)\n\nI still plan on making a \"why oddly satisfying videos are satisfying\" video at some point. Lab.", "tags": ["Discrete dislocation dynamics", "Hydrogen", "Diffusion", "Embrittlement", "Dislocations", "Pileup", "Edge Dislocations", "Hydrogen Ebrittlement", "Simulations", "DDD", "El-Awady"], "title": "Effect of hydrogen on the spacing between dislocations", "publishedAt": "2018-06-11T04:33:56Z", "description": "Discrete dislocation dynamics simulations of the effect of the presence of a hydrogen on the spacing between dislocations in an array of edge dislocations. The top case is for a material with a large hydrogen diffusion coefficient (e.g. Fe), while the bottom case is for a material with a small hydrogen diffusion coefficient. The colors indicate the H concentration mole fraction. The equilibrium mole fraction in both cases is 0.0005 and the applied shear stress is 100 MPa. The inverted \"T\" shows the position of the edge dislocations.\n\nFor more details about the simulation method, more details about the simulations, and for citation:\n\nYejun Gu, Jaafar A. After nine years of real-world experience and multiple long-term clinical studies, Prof. DDr. Ewers concludes that \u201cless is more\u201d!", "channelId": "UC-vzC5G_7MS09DIq1pHn6Qw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "8", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "526", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT24M19S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.02.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.02.001", "items": [{"id": "Zy11gkKKrqw", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "FRESH Prints", "tags": ["3D printing", "3D bioprinting", "open-source", "printrbot", "FRESH", "FRE", "FRE-3DP"], "title": "Large Volume Extruder (LVE) Assembly Instructions Video", "publishedAt": "2018-04-29T20:31:15Z", "description": "The large volume extruder (LVE) was developed by Kira Pusch and TJ Hinton in the Regenerative Biomaterials & Therapeutics Group, lead by Prof Adam Feinberg at Carnegie Mellon University.\n\nThe LVE is a syringe pump that is compatible with low-cost, open source 3D printers. Key aspects of the LVE include: (1) it is open source and compatible with open source hardware and software, making it inexpensive and widely accessible to the 3D printing community, (2) it utilizes a standard 60 mL syringe as its ink reservoir, effectively increasing print volume of the average bioprinter, (3) it is capable of retraction and high speed movements, and (4) it can print fluids using nozzle diameters as small as 100 \u03bcm, enabling the printing of complex shapes/objects when used in conjunction with the freeform reversible embedding of suspended hydrogels (FRESH) 3D printing method.   \n\nComplete instructions for printing, building and using the LVE are available in the open-access publication in the Journal Hardware X at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ohx.2018.02.001. All STL files can be downloaded under CC-BY license from the NIH 3D Print Exchange at https://3dprint.nih.gov/discover/3dpx-008366.", "channelId": "UCEwYrE9pROR0kinbDDSCFWg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "34", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "2", "viewCount": "1346", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT16M51S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.02.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.02.001", "items": [{"id": "Dtshb3n4Y6U", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Life Extension Advocacy Foundation", "tags": ["Aging", "Ageing", "Life Extension", "Rejuvenation", "LifeXtenShow", "X10", "Life Extension Advocacy Foundation", "LEAF", "Lifespan.io", "Science", "Biology", "Biotechnology", "cellular senescence", "senescent cells", "zombie cells"], "title": "The Hallmarks of Aging: Cellular senescence | LifeXtenShow", "publishedAt": "2020-05-21T14:59:21Z", "description": "Believe it or not, there probably are zombie cells in your body right now, and they\u2019re helping to stage one of the scariest molecular biology horror movies: aging.\n\nThanks to Kali Carrigan for writing the script!\n\nLiked the show? In this video, the normal anatomy of the human glans penis and the features of the glanular urethra are shown with MRI documentation. The split wings of the glans penis or so-called ventral cleft between the glans wings that accommodate the frenulum is part of normal anatomy. In hypospadias surgery, the approximated glans wings should allow for ventral support of the glanular and subcoronal urethra through a reconstructed neo-frenulum. Neither glanular surface enhancement nor extensive dissection of the glans wings and their full-length approximation are necessary, and may in fact be counter-productive. The employment of GFC (Glanular Frenular Collar) technique in hypospadias provides an anatomical restoration of the distal (glanular and subcoronal) urethra, supported by a neo-septum and frenulum.", "channelId": "UCqOLqSzMdGEjD3YYN8JPQ9A"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "706", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M6S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "EE9t6KTUmXY", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "es-419", "channelTitle": "Salud en Corto", "tags": ["Guillain barre", "Doctor vic", "mr doctor", "health", "trasplante de cabeza", "salud", "especialidad medica", "el internado", "blog de salud", "vacunas", "hospitales p\u00fablicos", "emergencia", "cirug\u00eda", "estudiante de medicina", "escuelas de medicina", "Med school", "steps", "cbd", "cannabis", "THC", "cannabis medicinial"], "title": "Todo sobre el CBD - Especial 4/20 | Dra. Epub 2017 Oct 3.\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------", "channelId": "UCEki4DboT5M7utF3RuK0vpA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "16", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "6", "viewCount": "618", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M12S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "Bl42bdpHVMo", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:22:52Z", "description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\nTourism as a heritage producing machine\nMaria Gravari-Barbas\n\nAbstract: The purpose of this document is to analyze the role that tourism has historically played and still plays today in the emergence and affirmation of the modern concept of heritage. It particularly looks to highlight the operational co-production of heritage and tourism and shows that tourism has never worked better, faster and more efficiently as a heritage-producing machine than in this beginning of the 21st century. We are on the threshold of a new \u201cheritage regime\u201d, which presents a gap compared with the one that produced the major European national heritages in the State-Nations of the 19th century. The tourism system (tourism actors, places and businesses as well as tourists themselves) contribute to the production of a new heritage system (heritage places, practices and actors) which functions according to its own needs and expectations, in a world of free traffic, transactions and generalized mobilities.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2018.01.004\n\n--\n\nMaking sense of heritage tourism: Research trends in a maturing field of study\nDallen Timothy\n\nAbstract: This essay examines several emerging research trends in the field of heritage tourism. These trends, including experiential connections with heritage, blurred boundaries between tourisms, more accurate portrayals of the commodified past and technological advancements, demonstrate a precipitous growth in heritage tourism scholarship that focuses more on experience, identity, stewardship, place and empowerment than the more descriptive supply v. demand work that preceded it. Changes in how researchers treat the cultural past indicate a maturing field of study that is increasing in popularity as a focus of academic research and also as a consumable tourist product.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.018", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Heritage Tourism (Maria Gravari-Barbas / Dallen Timothy, 2018)"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "150", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M13S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "3thvANq6O4E", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "de", "channelTitle": "Creative Artist", "tags": ["Altdeutsche H\u00fctehunde", "Jon Henrik Fj\u00e4llgren", "Hunter-Gatherers", "Sch\u00e4fer", "G\u00f6nnersdorf", "Oberkassel", "Bonn-Oberkassel", "jangara", "Sami", "Saami", "Evolution Hunde", "Laacher See", "Laacher Lake", "Vulkaneifel", "Eifel Vulkan"], "title": "Altdeutsche H\u00fctehunde - Herding Dogs", "publishedAt": "2017-05-08T16:43:24Z", "description": "Altdeutsche H\u00fctehunde (nonprofit Project)\nMusik: Jon Henrik Fj\u00e4llgren, Label Cupol\n\nWissenschaftliche Basis:\nMultistage damming of the Rhine River by tephra fallout during the 12,900 BP Plinian Laacher See Eruption (Germany). Syn-eruptive Rhine damming I\nCornelia Park, Hans-Ulrich Schminck at al 2019\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.jvolgeores.2019.106688\n\nA new look at an old dog: Bonn-Oberkassel reconsidered, Journal of Archaeological Science, Janssens at al 2018, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jas.2018.01.004\n\nAusbreitung der Ahrensburger und Hamburger Kultur nach Mittelengland, D\u00e4nemark und Schweden, derzeit datiert auf rund 9.600 v. Chr.  mit Anzeichen fr\u00fcherer nacheiszeitlicher Aktivit\u00e4ten. Hominide Gene belegen klar die Ausbreitung \u00fcber Doggerland nach England und Schottland sowie \u00fcber die D\u00e4nische Festlandbr\u00fccke nach Scane in Schweden sowie S\u00fcdnorwegen. Die westskandinavien Saamen (z.b. aus Lappland) zeigen daher eine h\u00f6here Abstammung von den Federmessergruppen Mitteleuropas (assoziiert mit Haplogruppe I2a2, Villanova Cluster). Diese waren auch die ersten Besiedler Skandinaviens. Einwanderer \u00fcber Russland sind ab ca. 8000 v. Chr. am Ladoga und Onager See nachweisbar und vermischten sich sp\u00e4ter im Hohen Norden zu den heutigen Saamen. Etwa ab 9000 Chr. wurde diese fr\u00fche  skandinavische Population (Komsa-Hensbakker-Fosna Kultur Complex) durch einen glazialen Kanal vom Kontinent getrennt, durch den die damalige Ostsee (Yoldiameer) \u00fcber den V\u00e4nner See abfloss. Erst nach 7700 v. Chr. entstand der Abfluss \u00fcber den Belt in den Kattegat. Beide J\u00e4ger und Sammler Kulturen trafen erneut aufeinander und es kam zur erneuten Ausbreitung kontinentaler J\u00e4ger und Sammler vom Kontinent aus der sich u.a. die Erteb\u00f6lle Kultur und weitere Ostsee-Kulturen dieser Zeit entwickelte. \nDNA Untersuchtungen an Hunden belegen das alle Nordeurop\u00e4ischen Hunde zum selben Genpool geh\u00f6rten und sich erst fr\u00fchestens in der Bronzezeit mit weiteren eingewanderten Hundepopulationen mischten. Der Hundegenpool war also bis ins sp\u00e4te Neolithikum/fr\u00fche Bronzezeit unbeeinflusst. (basierend auf Cherry Tree Cave, New Grange Dog, Norge Elk Dog, Saami Dogs und Samojeden) die auf die Domestikation eines Nordeurop\u00e4ischen Wolfes beruhen, gefunden in der Goyat-H\u00f6hle in Belgien. Diese Wolfspopulation ist ausgestorben.\nSaamische, Samojedische und Russische Hunde sind sp\u00e4ter in der Bronzezeit mit einer sibirischen Wolfspopulation (nachgewiesen auf der Tamyr Insel) gekreuzt worden. Englische Hunde mit einer eisenzeitlichen Hundepopulation die durch die R\u00f6mer verbreitet wurde und Wolfsgene aus Anatolien oder Asien trugen. \nUnklar ist ob die Domestikation von W\u00f6lfen ein einmaliges Ereignis mit weiterer Kreuzung wilder Wolfspopulationen in verschiedenen Ecken der Welt war wohin Hunde den Menschen folgten oder ob es verschiedene Domestikationen gab. Fraglich ist auch ob es \u00fcberhaupt eine aktive Domestikation gab oder es W\u00f6lfe einfach f\u00fcr bequemer fanden. sich dem Mensch zum Freund zu machen um von ihm Fressen zu bekommen. Paleolithische Untersuchungen zeigen, W\u00f6lfe folgen Menschen schon seit mehr als 50.000 Jahren und zeigen J\u00e4gern auch an, das keine B\u00e4ren in der N\u00e4he sind. Daher profitierten J\u00e4ger auch von der Anwesenheit wilder W\u00f6lf. Sofern sie keine Herde  sch\u00fctzen war der Wolf durchaus ein gern gesehener Nachbar der u.a. auch Nahrungsabf\u00e4lle beseitigte.\n\nDer plinischen Eruption folgten aufgestaute Seen bei Brohl und Koblenz, die f\u00fcr\nmehrere \u00dcberflutungen am darunter ablaufenden Rhein verantwortlich waren.\nIn dieser Studie wurde nur der Lake Brohl untersucht. Die Flutereignisse am Koblenzer See sind nicht beschrieben.\nIm sogenannten Lake Brohl wurden 5 Flutereignisse nachgewiesen,\nFlut unmittelbar nach der Eruption: Wasserstand 4,5 m\nFlut 1: 4m - hier staut sich das Bett des Rhein auf\nFlut 2: 7,5m - nun stauen sich auch die s\u00fcdlichen und n\u00f6rdlichen Arme auf\nFlut 3: 8,5m - das Land zwischen den Armen und dem Bett wird geflutet\nFlut 4: 11m - eine durchgehende Wasserdecke \u00fcber alle Seitenarme\nFlut 5: 12m - die Wasserdecke steigt \u00fcber alle Arme hinaus\ndabei wurden Steine bis zu einer Gr\u00f6\u00dfe einer Garage stromabw\u00e4rts transportiert,\naber auch die gesamte Ufervegetation inkl. dortiger W\u00e4lder die alle stromabw\u00e4rts\nfortgerissen wurden. \nMehrere Sto\u00dffluten mit erheblichem Druck wurden auch am englischen Kanal nachgewiesen wo das Wasser seit 100.000 Jahren den Damm abtrug und auch hier muss ja das Wasser irgendwoher kommen. Die letzte Trennung vom Festland erfolgte wohl im Zusammenhang mit der fortschreitenden Littorina-Transgression (Anhebung Skandinaviens) und Umformung der Ostsee, wodurch auch das Eifel Vulkanfeld aktiv war und derartige Flutevents ausl\u00f6ste, die ausreichten um die endg\u00fcltige Trennung Englands vom Kontinent zu vollenden.", "channelId": "UCvHzpeTXbVL8xJap-4-hR4Q"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "11", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "1466", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M34S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.004", "items": [{"id": "zcgtiSsly3M", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-06-21T09:18:02Z", "description": "Research Technical Document ENGL 3140\n\n218621.Pdf. https://publications.lib.chalmers.se/records/fulltext/218621/218621.pdf. Culex tarsalis are found almost everywhere in the U.S. and Canada. Study: http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/06/19/151951\n\nProblem is: the public has been inundated by millions of images of Aedes and repeatedly told \"daytime-active\" or \"daytime-biters\".\n\nYet, Culex tarsalis prefer to bite from sunset on. They are especially drawn to human feet and ankles.\n\nThe recommendation from the NEJM is that blood donors returning from any Zika-endemic area wait (at least) four months to donate blood. This also means that anyone returning from a Zika-endemic area should wear mosquito repellent every day for four months. Study: http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1613108#t=article\n\nBut there are no warnings about this or about Culex at all. Sfakianakis", "tags": ["Childhood", "sleep", "and", "adolescent", "chronic", "fatigue", "syndrome", "(CFS/ME):", "evidence", "of", "associations", "in", "UK", "birth", "cohort", "Simon", "Collin", "Tom", "Norris", "Paul", "Gringras", "Peter", "Blair", "Kate", "Tilling", "Esther", "Crawley'Correspondence", "information", "about", "the", "author", "CrawleyEmail", "Crawley", "Open", "Access", "DOI:", "https://doiorg/101016/jsleep2", "access", "funded", "by", "Medical", "Res"], "title": "Childhood sleep and adolescent chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME)", "publishedAt": "2018-02-01T13:15:42Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\nhttp://www.sleep-journal.com/article/S1389-9457(18)30017-0/fulltext?rss=yes\r\n\r\nChildhood sleep and adolescent chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME): evidence of associations in a UK birth cohort\r\nSimon M. Collin, Tom Norris, Paul Gringras, Peter S. Blair, Kate Tilling, Esther Crawley'Correspondence information about the author Esther CrawleyEmail the author Esther Crawley\r\nOpen Access\r\nDOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.sleep.2018.01.005\r\nOpen access funded by Medical Research Council\r\n\r\nhideArticle Info\r\nPublication History\r\nPublished online: February 01, 2018\r\nAccepted: January 8, 2018\r\nReceived in revised form: January 6, 2018\r\nReceived: April 25, 2017\r\nUser License\r\nCreative Commons Attribution (CC BY 4.0) How you can reuse  Information Icon\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nSupplemental Materials\r\nArticle Outline\r\n1. Background\r\n2. Methods\r\n2.1. Study cohort\r\n2.2. Classification of CFS/ME\r\n2.3. Sleep measurements\r\n2.4. Statistical analysis\r\n2.4.1. Sleep patterns from age 6 months to 11 years in relation to CDF during adolescence\r\n2.4.2. Association of sleep with CDF adjusted for potential confounders\r\n2.4.2.1. Outcomes\r\n2.4.2.2. Primary exposures\r\n2.4.2.3. Other variables\r\n2.4.2.4. Missing data and multiple imputation\r\n3. Results\r\n3.1. Sleep patterns from age 6 months to 11 years\r\n3.2. Associations of sleep duration with CDF\r\n3.2.1. Sleep at age 9 and CDF at age 13\r\n3.2.2. Sleep at age 11 and CDF at age 16\r\n4. Discussion\r\nStrengths and weaknesses\r\nOur findings in the context of the studies\r\n5. Conclusions and future work\r\nFunding\r\nAcknowledgement\r\nAppendix A. Supplementary data\r\nReferences\r\nGoHighlights\r\n\u2022Children who develop chronic disabling fatigue (CDF) in adolescence have shorter nighttime sleep duration throughout early childhood.\r\n\u2022For each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 9, the odds of CDF at age 13 were 40% lower, and for each additional hour at age 11, the odds of CDF at age 16 were 50% lower.\r\n\u2022Sleep abnormalities may have a causal role in CFS/ME, or sleep abnormalities and CFS/ME are related to a common pathophysiological cause.\r\nGoAbstract\r\nObjective\r\n/Background: Sleep abnormalities are characteristic of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS, also known as \u2018ME\u2019), but it is not known whether sleep might be a causal risk factor for CFS/ME.\r\n\r\nPatients/Methods\r\nWe analysed data from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC) birth cohort. We describe sleep patterns from age 6 months to 11 years in children who were subsequently classified as having (or not having) \u2018chronic disabling fatigue\u2019 (CDF, a proxy for CFS/ME) between ages 13-18 years, and investigate associations of sleep duration at age 9 with CDF at age 13, and sleep duration at age 11 with CDF at age 16 years.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nChildren who had CDF during adolescence had shorter nighttime sleep duration from age 6 months to age 11 years, and there was strong evidence that difficulties in going to sleep were more common in children who subsequently developed CDF. The odds of CDF at age 13 were 39% lower (odds ratio (OR) = 0.61, 95% CI 0.43, 0.88) for each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 9 years, and the odds of CDF at age 16 were 51% lower (OR = 0.49, 95% CI 0.34, 0.70) for each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 11. Mean nighttime sleep duration at age 9 was 13.9 (95% CI 3.75, 24.0) minutes shorter among children who developed CDF at age 13, and sleep duration at age 11 was 18.7 (95% CI 9.08, 28.4) minutes shorter among children who developed CDF at age 16 (compared with children who did not develop CDF at 13 and 16, respectively).\r\n\r\nConclusions\r\nChildren who develop chronic disabling fatigue in adolescence have shorter nighttime sleep duration throughout early childhood, suggesting that sleep abnormalities may have a causal role in CFS/ME or that sleep abnormalities and CFS/ME are related to a common pathophysiological cause.\r\n\r\nKeywords:\r\npaediatric, adolescence, chronic fatigue syndrome, CFS/ME, sleep, ALSPAC\r\nGo1. Background\r\nChronic fatigue syndrome (CFS, also known as \u2018ME\u2019) in children and young people is a debilitating disease with an adverse impact on the lives of children and their families [[1], [2], [3]]. UK National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines state that diagnosis of CFS/ME should be made after 3 months of persistent or recurrent fatigue which is not the result of ongoing exertion, not s", "channelId": "UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "24", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M41S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.005", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.005", "items": [{"id": "AyUQg6HQCPM", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "zxx", "channelTitle": "Tanmay Patel", "tags": ["#COVID-19", "#Corona", "#COVID 19", "#lung", "#lungs", "#CD147", "#micromechanics", "#coronavirus", "#Coronavirus", "#prevention", "#covidprevention", "#howcoronaenters", "#pathogenesis", "#pathophysiology", "#howcoronaentersourbody", "#BreakthroughJuniorChallenge", "#breakthroughjuniorchallenge", "#breakthroughjuniorchallenge2020"], "title": "COVID-19: Mechanism of action on lungs. In the opening scenes, the video presents the popular topic of autonomous sensory meridian response (ASMR), where a tingling sensation is felt in the body due to auditory or visual stimuli. To display both sets of reactions, a youtube react portion is incorporated within the video, where participants show the reactions of individuals who either experience ASMR videos positively or negatively. The diagnostic criteria of misophonia are then explained along with some neurological differences between individuals with and without misophonia. \n\nFor those that want to learn more about ASMR please click the link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vCPYwnD8D5I \n\n\nThis video was made by McMaster Demystifying Medicine students Ripley Antonacci, Sehar Arfeen, Monica Chu and Sabrin Salim. \n\nCopyright McMaster University 2019\n\nReferences\n\nCavanna, A. A review of current measures identified fourteen common constructs as lower-order indicators of well-being: happiness, vitality, calmness, optimism, involvement, self-awareness, self-acceptance, self-worth, competence, development, purpose, significance, self-congruence and connection. Three studies were then conducted. In study 1, the item pool was developed and the adequacy of its content to assess each of the fourteen constructs was evaluated by consulting a panel of six subject expert academics. In study 2, the dimensionality was assessed in an adult North American sample (N=560). The results supported the hierarchical factor structure. In study 3, further evidence confirmed the factor structure, and provided support for the measure's internal and test-retest reliability, measurement invariance across gender, age and a longitudinal period of 5weeks, and criterion validity in an adult North American sample (N=1101). The SGWB promises to be a useful research tool that provides both a global measure of well-being as well as a collection of fourteen individual health-related scales.\nKeywords: Scale development; Scale validation; Bifactor; Higher-order; Well-being; Measurement; Quality of life\n\nShort form: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327102158_14-item_Scales_of_General_Well-Being_14-SGWB \nYlenio Longo, Iain Coyne, Stephen Joseph,\nDevelopment of the short version of the Scales of General Well-Being: The 14-item SGWB,\nPersonality and Individual Differences,\nVolume 124,\n2018,\nPages 31-34,\nISSN 0191-8869,\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.042.\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886917306992)\nAbstract: The Scales of General Well-Being (SGWB, Longo, Coyne, & Joseph, 2017) is a 65-item tool assessing fourteen different constructs. The aim of this study was to develop a short 14-item version. One item was chosen from each of the fourteen scales following inspection of previously-published factor loadings and content validity ratings. In total, 446 responses from U.S residents were collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk. Results supported a factor structure consistent with the long form, as well as good internal consistency. Additionally, general well-being scores of short- and long-form correlated at 0.96 and each item in the short-form was strongly related to its respective long-form scale. The 14-item SGWB offers a brief assessment of well-being based on a novel and comprehensive operational definition, and promises to be of practical use to researchers and clinicians.\nKeywords: Well-being; Short form; SGWB; Flourishing; Measurement; Scale; Validation; Factor analysis\n\nIntroductory article\nhttps://www.psychologytoday.com/gb/blog/what-doesnt-kill-us/201708/what-exactly-is-well-being\n\nThis research was supported by the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) grant ES/J500100/1 to Ylenio Longo", "channelId": "UCOacNQKVcIj8k-PCwarBdlg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "16", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M51S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.01.005", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.01.005", "items": [{"id": "tYFZuUZlFdY", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Dandi Anastasa", "tags": ["Clustering", "K-Means Clustering", "ArcGIS", "Journal", "Buku", "Article", "Science Direct", "Cara Download di Science Direct", "Data Mining", "Kutipan", "Delta State University", "Mississippi", "USA. 2017", "Hui-Peng Liew", "Talbot Brooks", "Suntoro Joko", "Spatial clusters of AIDS in Indonesia", "Using Cluster Analysis Study to Examine the Successful Performance Entrepreneur in Indonesia", "Santi Setyaningsih", "ITB", "SBM ITB", "Procedia Economic", "Finance", "camtasia", "kuyhaa", "teknologi", "Klasifikasi Data", "Naive Beyes", "Algoritma", "C4.5"], "title": "Assignment 11 - (Neuroscience and Pleasure)", "publishedAt": "2020-04-29T18:00:17Z", "description": "First 200 people to use this link https://brilliant.org/WIL/ can get 20% off an annual premium subscription to Brilliant!\n\n\u25bcNewsletter signup: https://mailchi.mp/a58275fd1906/josepheverettwil\n\u25b2Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/WILearned\n\u25b2Twitter: https://twitter.com/jeverettlearned\n\u25b2IG: https://www.instagram.com/jeverett.whativelearned/\n\nBooks:\nJeffrey Schwartz's \"Brain Lock\" - https://amzn.to/2VP0dKI\nJaak Panksepp's \"Affective Neuroscience\" - https://amzn.to/3f3fv5U\nAnjan Chatterjee's \"The Aesthetic Brain\" - https://amzn.to/3bTQGre\nMihaly Csikszentmihalyi's \"Flow\" - https://amzn.to/2WaIfkH\nGregory Bern's \"Satisfaction!\" - https://amzn.to/2SmmfSL\n\n---\nI actually started out working on this video with the aim to understand why \"oddly satisfying\" videos are satisfying. I figured the first step with that was to figure out why *anything* is satisfying. Since we call a lot of things satisfying, this was harder than I expected. When things are in perfect sync it's satisfying, when things are in perfect order is satisfying, it's satisfying when you are arranging your new living room and then the short square table you have fits perfectly between your two sofas and the surface of the table is flush with both sofa's arm rests. (Fun fact: in Japanese, you just say \"feels good\" (kimochi ii) for things like this) Unsurprisingly, there's not much research on the concept of \"satisfying.\"  \n\nThen I started looking into why we find things pleasurable. Jaak Panksepp says that things that are pleasurable are *biologically useful* . So it was even more curious that things seemingly irrelevant to keeping us alive should make us feel good.  \n\nThis video is the result of cobbling a bit of logic with information from books on Satisfaction, neuroscience, 'what the brain finds beautiful' as well as various research papers on the brain. I hope it's satisfying. \n\n(If editing videos didn't take so gotham long,  this video would be about an hour)\n\nI still plan on making a \"why oddly satisfying videos are satisfying\" video at some point. The top case is for a material with a large hydrogen diffusion coefficient (e.g. Fe), while the bottom case is for a material with a small hydrogen diffusion coefficient. The colors indicate the H concentration mole fraction. The equilibrium mole fraction in both cases is 0.0005 and the applied shear stress is 100 MPa. And it will add up to - not replace - our current technologies. So why is 4G not enough? 4G has been designed to meet the needs of people. But 5G has been created with the machines\u2019 needs in mind. 5G will offer transmission speeds powerful enough to accomodate The Internet Of Things. All the devices you can think of that can be switched on and off will be connected to the internet. It\u2019s estimated that over 24 billion devices will be connected to the internet of things by 2020. The idea behind 5G is to use untapped bandwidth of extremely high-frequency millimeter waves, between 30GHz and 300GHz in addition to what\u2019s already being used. High frequency millimeter waves travel a short distance, and don\u2019t travel well through buildings, and tend to get absorbed by plants and rain. To counter this problem 5G will utilize smaller cell stations. This means thousands of wireless antennas in our neighbourhoods. They will be placed on street lamps, houses, schools, churches, shops and even trees. There has been very little research done on the effects of millimeter waves on our health and environment.  \u201c5G technology is a very real danger,\u201d warns Dr. Moskowitz, a public health professor at the University of California. \u201cThe deployment of 5G, or fifth generation cellular technology, constitutes a massive experiment on the health of all species,\u201d he said. In September 2017 the  EU 5G Appeal, signed by more than 180 scientists and doctors from 35 nations was  submitted  to the European Commission demanding a moratorium on the increase of cell/mobile antennas for planned 5G expansion. \n\nRisks from 5G include:\nDamage to the eyes \u2013 cataracts, retinal damage\nSevere sweating\nSkin damage\nImmune system disruption\nMetabolic disruption\nNeurological disturbance\nLeakage of blood brain barrier\nDamage to sperm\nIncreased risk of cancers\nDepression and suicide\nCollapse of insect populations, the base of food for birds and bats\nRise in bacterial resistance and bacterial shifts\nDamage to plants and trees\n\n\u201cThe 5G millimeter wave is known to heat the eyes, skin and testes... Perder grasa es un proceso que requiere conocimiento, tiempo y esfuerzo. Por suerte, la literatura cient\u00edfica ha acumulado mucho conocimiento en las \u00faltimas d\u00e9cadas sobre el proceso de lip\u00f3lisis y oxidaci\u00f3n de \u00e1cidos grasos, es decir, sobre c\u00f3mo tu organismo consigue eliminar grasa. \n\nHoy te traigo 6 consejos basados en la literatura cient\u00edfica, y tambi\u00e9n en mi experiencia, que te ayudar\u00e1n a perder grasa si los llegas a implementar. \n\nNecesito de tu feedback. Por favor, comenta lo que te gusta y lo que no. Lo que necesitas, lo que te gustar\u00eda ver, lo que te parece superfluo. Es la \u00fanica forma que tengo de mejorar. \n\nSi consideras que aporto algo de valor en \u00e9ste v\u00eddeo dejo a tu elecci\u00f3n la posibilidad de subscribirte y dar un like. Zapocz\u0105tkowa\u0142y one badania naturalnej historii cz\u0142owieka, kt\u00f3re dzisiaj opieraj\u0105 si\u0119 nie tylko na wykopaliskach i analizie skamienia\u0142o\u015bci pozostawionych przez naszych przodk\u00f3w, ale tak\u017ce na badaniach staro\u017cytnego DNA.\n\nCo dzi\u015b wiemy na pewno o naszych w\u0142asnych pocz\u0105tkach? Jak wygl\u0105da\u0142y losy populacji, kt\u00f3ra niegdy\u015b rozdzieli\u0142a si\u0119 na linie ewolucyjne prowadz\u0105ce do ludzi oraz szympans\u00f3w? The larger eddies in the turbulent flow are resolved using Large Eddy Simulations (LES) and the particle-particle and particle-wall interactions are resolved using the soft-sphere Discrete Element Method (DEM). The two phases are two-way coupled.\n\nSimulation parameters are:\nPeriodic domain with length, L/D = 4\nParticle size, dp/D = 0.005\nNumber of particle, np = 48,000\nReynolds number, Re = 10,000\nStokes number, St = 0.8\nParticle volume fraction, phi = 0.001\nParticle elasticity parameter, lambda = 500\nParticle adhesiveness parameter, Ad = 0.05\nAdhesion hysteresis parameter, gamma* = 0.5\nCoefficient of restitution, e = 0.3\n\nMore information can be found in the following publications:\n\nH\u00e6rvig, J. \"On the Adhesive Behaviour of Micron-sized Particles in Turbulent Flow: A Numerical Study Coupling the Discrete Element Method and Large Eddy Simulations\", PhD Thesis, Aalborg University, 2017\ndoi: 10.5278/vbn.phd.eng.00022\n\nH\u00e6rvig et al. \"Early stages of agglomeration of adhesive particles in fully-developed turbulent pipe flows\", International Journal of Multiphase Flow 106 (2018) pp. 254-267\ndoi: 10.1016/j.ijmultiphaseflow.2018.04.017\n\nH\u00e6rvig et al. \"On the adhesive JKR contact and rolling models for reduced particle stiffness discrete element simulations\", Powder Technology 319 (2017) pp. 472-482\ndoi: 10.1016/j.powtec.2017.07.006\n\nYear: 2017\nPhD Student: Jakob H\u00e6rvig\nSupervision: Kim S\u00f8rensen and Thomas J. To avoid this drawback, this work aims to obtain a photocatalyst easily removable from aqueous media using magnetism. The core@shell system (Co,Mn)Fe2O4@TiO2 was prepared by adding commercial (Co,Mn)Fe2O4 nanoparticles to the titanium polymeric resin synthesized by the modified Pechini method. Optimization of photocatalyst properties was achieved by variation of the TiO2:ferrite ratio, synthesis temperature and time, followed by their evaluation in photodegradation of an azo dye. The highest efficiency was attained when anatase was the major crystalline phase, whereas TiO2:ferrite ratio was limited to 90% to retain the magnetic properties, which enabled its removal from aqueous media using simple magnets. The system (Co,Mn)Fe2O4@TiO2, synthesized with 90% TiO2 and calcined at 500\u202f\u00b0C for 8\u202fh, presented a discoloration of 76.3% after 16\u202fh of exposure to UV light.\n\nAuthors: A. M. Neris, W. H. Schreiner, C. Salvador, U. C. Silva, C. Chesman, E. Longo & I. M. G. Frontiers in Behavioral Neuroscience, 13. doi: 10.3389/fnbeh.2019.00066", "channelId": "UCIFU0IrrjgLaL9SklP6_Hjw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "19", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "2", "viewCount": "269", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT19M16S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.037", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.037", "items": [{"id": "ckxmx8BsIgg", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["Curent Biology"], "title": "Visual Features in the Perception of Liquids", "publishedAt": "2018-02-03T18:06:31Z", "description": "Visual Features in the Perception of Liquids. Jan Jaap R. van Assen et al (2018), Curent Biology https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2017.12.037\n\nPerceptual constancy\u2014identifying surfaces and objects across large image changes\u2014remains an important challenge for visual neuroscience. Liquids are particularly challenging because they respond to external forces in complex, highly variable ways, presenting an enormous range of images to the visual system. To achieve constancy, the brain must perform a causal inference  that disentangles the liquid\u2019s viscosity from external factors\u2014like gravity and object interactions\u2014that also affect the liquid\u2019s behavior. Here, we tested whether the visual system estimates viscosity using \u201cmidlevel\u201d features that respond more to viscosity than other factors. Observers reported the perceived viscosity of simulated liquids ranging from water to molten glass exhibiting diverse behaviors (e.g., pouring, stirring). A separate group of observers rated the same animations for 20 midlevel 3D shape and motion features. Applying factor analysis to the feature ratings reveals that a weighted combination of four underlying factors (distribution, irregularity, rectilinearity, and dynamics) predicted perceived viscosity very well across this wide range of contexts (R2 = 0.93). Interestingly, observers unknowingly ordered their midlevel judgments according to the one common factor across contexts: variation in viscosity. Principal component analysis reveals that across the features, the first component lines up almost perfectly with the viscosity (R2 = 0.96). Our findings demonstrate that the visual system achieves constancy by representing stimuli in a multidimensional feature space\u2014based on complementary, midlevel features\u2014which successfully cluster very different stimuli together and tease similar stimuli apart, so that viscosity can be read out easily.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "46", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M1S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.037", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.037", "items": [{"id": "JbS8dJJt4Kk", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-05-03T15:34:56Z", "description": "", "channelTitle": "Alex G", "channelId": "UCCeyvcFkV9C5pCFIR60zPqw", "title": "Golata Research Talk"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", M. Weinstein et al. Br J Anaesth 2018; 120(5): 999-1008\r\n\r\n This is an American single center retrospective study with 41,766 patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasties over a seven year period.&nbsp; They showed that 22.1% patients developed post operative delirium according to the ICD 9 definition of delirium.&nbsp; Delirium occurs more in patients with multiple co-morbidities, older age, higher baseline creatinine, lower haemoglobins and longer patients stays.\r\n\r\n They looked at the type of anaesthetic as well as the use of opioids, ketamine and benzodiazepines.&nbsp; They found the rates of delirium were higher in the knee arthroplasty group compared with the hip arthroplasty group.\r\n\r\n Those that received a neuroaxial block had a lower rate of delirium; Spinal:&nbsp; OR 0.55 (CI 0.37-0.83), Epidural:&nbsp; OR 0.59 (CI&nbsp; 0.38-0.93), CSE:&nbsp; OR0.56 (CI 0.40-0.80).&nbsp; There was a high risk with the use of postoperative benzodiazepines (OR 2.47 CI 2.04-2.97) and ketamine infusion ()R 10.59 CI 5.26-19.91) as well as intraoperative ketamine (OR 1.27 CI 1.01-1.59)&nbsp; and opioids (OR 10.59 CI 5.26-19.91).&nbsp;", "channelTitle": "TopMedTalk", "channelId": {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.048", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.048", "items": [{"id": "ZWLvUkPus0g", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-08-11T10:05:59Z", "description": "Contributor: Don Stader, MD\r\n\r\n Educational Pearls:\r\n\r\n  Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a rare cause of shock typically caused by Staph aureus or Strep pyogenes, that produces a toxin that leads to rapid onset hypotension with a diffuse erythematous rash. Signs of TSS may include rapid onset of altered mental status, dizziness, nausea, abdominal discomfort, hypotension, and rash TSS is associated with foreign bodies, such as tampons or nasal packing - make sure to remove any offending object Clindamycin is the drug of choice because it stops protein synthesis which helps treat toxic shock because toxic shock is caused by a protein (TSST-1) made by the bacteria.   TSS is associated iwth high morbidity and mortality despite treatments Despite the association with TSS, there is little supporting evidence for prophylactic antibiotics when placing nasal packing  References\r\n\r\n Gottlieb M, Long B, Koyfman A. The Evaluation and Management of Toxic Shock Syndrome in the Emergency Department: A Review of the Literature. J Emerg Med. 2018;54(6):807-814. doi:10.1016/j.jemermed.2017.12.048\r\n\r\n Lange JL, Peeden EH, Stringer SP. Are prophylactic systemic antibiotics necessary with nasal packing? A systematic review. Am J Rhinol Allergy. 2017;31(4):240-247. doi:10.2500/ajra.2017.31.4454\r\n\r\n Summarized by Jackson Roos, MS4 | Edited by Erik Verzemnieks, MD", "channelTitle": "Emergency Medical Minute", "channelId": "UCl7JiDqtvbRQizZF85gsgqw", "title": "Podcast 586:\u00a0 Toxic Shock Syndrome"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "19", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M33S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.049", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.049", "items": [{"id": "JqQ2rIohqnI", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["Current Biology"], "title": "Pupil Size Coupling to Cortical States Protects the Stability of Deep Sleep via Parasympathetic", "publishedAt": "2018-01-20T19:00:51Z", "description": "Pupil Size Coupling to Cortical States Protects the Stability of Deep Sleep via Parasympathetic Modulation. \u00d6zge Y\u00fczge\u00e7 et al (2018), Current Biology https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2017.12.049\n\nDuring wakefulness, pupil diameter can reflect changes in attention, vigilance, and cortical states. How pupil size relates to cortical activity during sleep, however, remains unknown. Pupillometry during natural sleep is inherently challenging since the eyelids are usually closed. Here, we present a novel head-fixed sleep paradigm in combination with infrared back-illumination pupillometry (iBip) allowing robust tracking of pupil diameter in sleeping mice. We found that pupil size can be used as a reliable indicator of sleep states and that cortical activity becomes tightly coupled to pupil size fluctuations during non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Pharmacological blocking experiments indicate that the observed pupil size changes during sleep are mediated via the parasympathetic system. We furthermore found that constrictions of the pupil during NREM episodes might play a protective role for stability of sleep depth. These findings reveal a fundamental relationship between cortical activity and pupil size, which has so far been hidden behind closed eyelids.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "144", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M25S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.049", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.049", "items": [{"id": "JYGCgwKC8F8", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Reza Aghlara", "tags": ["Metallic Yield damper", "Bar-Fuse Damper", "BFD", "Energy Dissipating Device", "Passive Control", "Metallic damper", "Hysteretic Deivce"], "title": "BFD Animation Reza Aghlara", "publishedAt": "2018-04-27T13:07:23Z", "description": "Bar-Fuse Damper (BFD) is a metallic yield damper in which steel bars dissipate energy through plastic bending deformation. M. Dudik, J. L. Coyle, A. El-Jaroudi, Z.-H. Mao, M. Sun, E. Sejdi\u0107, \u201cDeep learning for classification of normal swallows in adults,\u201d Neurocomputing, vol. 285, pp. 1-9, Apr. 2018.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.neucom.2017.12.059\n\nABSTRACT:\nCervical auscultation is a method for assessing swallowing performance. However, its ability to serve as a classification tool for a practical clinical assessment method is not fully understood. In this study, we utilized neural network classification methods in the form of Deep Belief networks in order to classify swallows. We specifically utilized swallows that did not result in clinically significant aspiration and classified them on whether they originated from healthy subjects or unhealthy patients. Dual-axis swallowing vibrations from 1946 discrete swallows were recorded from 55 healthy and 53 unhealthy subjects. The Fourier transforms of both signals were used as inputs to the networks of various sizes. We found that single and multi-layer Deep Belief networks perform nearly identically when analyzing only a single vibration signal. However, multi-layered Deep Belief networks demonstrated approximately a 5\u201310% greater accuracy and sensitivity when both signals were analyzed concurrently, indicating that higher-order relationships between these vibrations are important for classification and assessment.", "channelId": "UCZTmNHUz63iphbhJc6d__JA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", This video is part of the supplementary materials for the research article - a drone survey of the cliff face with a view of some of the oldest paintings at the site. Shot with a Parrot Bebop.\n\nRock art at the cave of a thousand Buddhas, Luang Prabang, Lao PDR\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ara.2018.01.001\n\nThe rock art of the Pak Ou Caves in Luang Prabang, Lao PDR has been known for over 20 years, but to date a complete record of the site has not been made. This paper presents an inventory of the rock art found at site also known as the Cave of a Thousand Buddhas. Over 50 rock art elements, mostly paintings, have been found in the upper cave and on the cliff face overlooking the junction of the Mekong and Ou Rivers. The oldest red paintings depict domesticated buffalo, human figures and hand prints and bear similarities with other cliff-side rock art sites in highland Southeast Asia. Other paintings are associated with the conversion of the cave into a Buddhist shrine, which according to folk tradition was home to a powerful river spirit. The most recent paintings can be comfortably dated to the 20th century. The Pak Ou Caves are a significant Buddhist site today, but the variety of rock art suggests its significance predates the Buddhist period that began in the 15th century. The layered history of the site and its rock art attests to multiple episodes of site use and re-use, from possibly the Neolithic until today.", "channelId": "UC51QJiAAN20LOCtSXuJAetg", "defaultLanguage": "en-GB"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "viewCount": "99", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M29S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "qFEV4K9hUq8", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en-US", "channelTitle": "Nat Geo WILD", "tags": ["nat geo wild", "national geographic", "wild", "wildlife", "animals", "nat geo", "natgeo", "science", "discover", "nature", "documentary", "cuttlefish", "mimicry", "crabs", "squid", "fish", "nerves", "PLNxd9fYeqXeYQaV1z9-tWQXJBeq_s8hX9", "Like Crabs", "Like Algae", "Like Rocks", "new study", "study examines", "muscles", "chemicals", "enable cuttlefish", "change their skin", "texture", "mimicking", "surroundings", "Cuttlefish Look Like Squid", "A new study examines", "examines the muscles", "animals related to squid", "skin texture", "mimicking another animal"], "title": "Cuttlefish Look Like Squid\u2014and Like Crabs, and Like Algae, and Like Rocks | Nat Geo Wild", "publishedAt": "2018-02-20T13:00:04Z", "description": "A new study examines the muscles, nerves, and chemicals that enable cuttlefish\u2014animals related to squid\u2014to change their skin texture, mimicking another animal or their surroundings. \n\u27a1 Subscribe: http://bit.ly/NatGeoWILDSubscribe\n\nAbout National Geographic Wild:\nNational Geographic Wild is a place for all things animals and for animal-lovers alike. Take a journey through the animal kingdom with us and discover things you never knew before, or rediscover your favorite animals!\n\nGet More National Geographic Wild: \nOfficial Site: http://bit.ly/NatGeoWILD\nFacebook: http://bit.ly/NGWFacebook\nTwitter: http://bit.ly/NGWTwitter\nInstagram: http://bit.ly/NGWInstagram\n\nWhen little bumps all over their skin, called papillae, stick out, two kinds of muscles are involved in the display. One kind, striated muscles\u2014like skeletal muscles, such as your biceps\u2014help the cuttlefish raise the spiny nubs fast. Another kind, which are similar to the smooth muscles in your gut, seem to allow the bumps to stay up for as long as an hour without using much energy. Gonzales-Bellido and her collaborators also discovered that the a secondary nerve bundle, not the brain, controls the muscles, which hints at a deep evolutionary connection to a similar neural circuit in squid.\n\nRead the related article \"Cuttlefish Pretend to be Crabs to Catch More Fish.\"\nhttps://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/cuttlefish-mimics-hermit-crabs-catch-fish/\n\nCuttlefish Look Like Squid\u2014and Like Crabs, and Like Algae, and Like Rocks | Nat Geo Wild\nhttps://youtu.be/qFEV4K9hUq8\n\nNat Geo Wild \nhttps://www.youtube.com/user/NatGeoWild", "channelId": "UCDPk9MG2RexnOMGTD-YnSnA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "387", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "22", "viewCount": "15929", "dislikeCount": "6"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M5S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "E1SVufh-0zE", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2019-12-10T18:48:59Z", "description": "Becker, S. "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "epAnsWDVMQQ", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Otolaryngologist,ORL,ENT-Medical Office,Artz Praxis", "tags": ["Treatment", "of", "chronic", "tinnitus", "Transcranial", "direct", "current", "stimulation"], "title": "Treatment of chronic tinnitus : Transcranial direct current stimulation", "publishedAt": "2018-01-08T13:20:15Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\nEffect of transcranial direct current stimulation on short-term and long-term treatment of chronic tinnitus\r\nHamidreza Abtahi, Ahmadreza Okhovvat, Somaiie Heidari, Azar Gharagazarloo, Motahare Mirdamadi, Mohammad Hossein Nilforoush, Hossein Ghazavi'Correspondence information about the author Hossein GhazaviEmail the author Hossein Ghazavi\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.amjoto.2018.01.001\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nReferences\r\nAbstract\r\nObjective\r\nThis study was conducted to investigate the effectiveness of anodal and cathodal methods in reducing the intensity of tinnitus and to compare them with the control.\r\n\r\nMethodology\r\nThis randomized double-blind clinical trial with case and control groups was conducted in Al-Zahra Hospital in Isfahan between 2015 and 2016. In this trial, 51 patients with tinnitus, for at least one year, were selected among those outpatients visiting the throat, nose and ear clinic within this period. Inclusion criteria were patients on electrical stimulation prohibition, with M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease, otosclerosis, chronic headache, and pulsatile tinnitus. Patients were randomly divided in three equal-sized groups: anodal stimulation group, cathodal stimulation group, and control group. The subjects received 20-min current stimulation (2\u202fmA). Five subjects were selected from those with a significant difference between the stimulated states (anodal or cathodal) and/or control. They received weekly transcranial electrical stimulation for two months, and their long-term recovery from tinnitus was investigated. Data analysis was done with SPSS20.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nFindings showed no significant between-groups difference in mean scores of tinnitus before the intervention (p\u202f=\u202f.68); whereas, this difference was significant immediately after the intervention (p\u202f=\u202f.02) and 1\u202fh after it (p\u202f=\u202f.03). The mean score of tinnitus in the anodal stimulation group was significantly lower than the control; whereas, no significant difference was observed between the anodal and cathodal stimulation groups, and between the cathodal and control groups (p\u202f\u202f.05). Findings also showed that the mean scores of tinnitus in two cathodal stimulation groups (p\u202f=\u202f.24) and control group (p\u202f=\u202f.62) were not significantly different at three different points of time; whereas, this score was significantly different in the anodal group at these time points (p\u202f=\u202f.01).\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nIn conclusion, anodal stimulation was more effective than the cathodal and control stimulation in reducing the intensity of tinnitus in the short term.\r\n\r\nKeywords:\r\nTinnitus, Cathodal stimulation, Anodal stimulation, Transcranial direct current stimulation\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelId": "UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "255", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M56S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "0YnHRl7bat4", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Semergen", "tags": ["SEMERGEN", "SEMERGEN18", "acods", "anticoagulados"], "title": "Mesa: Trabajo en equipo multidisciplinar en la anticoagulaci\u00f3n: todo son ventajas", "publishedAt": "2018-10-18T12:26:15Z", "description": "M\u00e1s informaci\u00f3n en: www.semergen.es\nwww.congresonacionalsemergen.com", "channelId": "UCeBBhbr7yJX7rGqysAdySUQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "114", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "liveStreamingDetails": {"actualStartTime": "2018-10-18T10:30:13.496000Z"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H36M10S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "uI53kHhptjs", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Semergen", "tags": ["SEMERGEN", "ANTICOAGULADOS", "ANTICOAGULANTES", "ACO", "ACOs"], "title": "Mesa: Trabajo en equipo multidisciplinar en la anticoagulaci\u00f3n: todo son ventajas", "publishedAt": "2019-01-14T16:46:27Z", "description": "Moderadores:\nDr. D. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRisk factors of sensorineural hearing loss in patients with unilateral safe chronic suppurative otitis media\r\nAbd Elrheem Ahmed Singer, Osama G. Abdel-Naby Awad'Correspondence information about the author Osama G. Abdel-Naby AwadEmail the author Osama G. Abdel-Naby Awad, Rafeek Mohamed Abd El-Kader, Ahmed Rabeh Mohamed\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.amjoto.2018.01.002\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nReferences\r\nAbstract\r\nPurpose\r\nChronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the major cause of hearing impairment, especially conductive hearing loss. Few patients also had sensorineural component, the sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in CSOM is controversial, especially for safe mucosal type. This study aims to assess the relationship between the frequency of SNHL development in patients with safe mucosal CSOM and its relation to patient's age, sex, duration of disease, size of perforation and different audiological findings.\r\n\r\nMaterial and methods\r\nThis is a prospective study conducted from June 2016 to June 2017 in a tertiary referral hospital. 200 patients with unilateral mucosal type of CSOM with normal contralateral ear were included in the study. The diseased ears were taken as study ears and normal ears as control ears in all patients. Detailed otologic history, clinical and audiometric findings were recorded and analyzed. Results were statistically compared in all patients for both study and control ears using different parameters.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nTwenty patients had an average bone conduction threshold of all frequencies above 25\u2005dB, which implies SNHL (10%). The incidence of SNHL was statistically significant at higher speech frequencies. The incidence increased with the presence of Diabetes Mellitus, smoking, duration of disease, presence of active discharge and the increase in size of perforation. However, it is not age dependent and there was no difference between males and females.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nSafe mucosal CSOM can cause SNHL with multiple predisposing factors.\n\r\n\r- video upload Maryland USA: Rowman & Littlefield\n\n#habiaspensado\n#fortnite\n#edutubers", "channelId": "UC-vEfub10tVpZItr-n_Haog"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "668", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "120", "viewCount": "10367", "dislikeCount": "67"}, "liveStreamingDetails": {"actualStartTime": "2019-02-09T18:00:10Z"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT8M10S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.012", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.012", "items": [{"id": "PRq4rgAzOs0", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["Current Biology", "Praying Mantis"], "title": "A Novel Form of Stereo Vision in the Praying Mantis", "publishedAt": "2018-02-19T19:28:03Z", "description": "A Novel Form of Stereo Vision in the Praying Mantis. Vivek Nityananda et al (2018), Current Biology https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2018.01.012\n\nStereopsis is the ability to estimate distance based on the different views seen in the two eyes. It is an important model perceptual system in neuroscience and a major area of machine vision. Mammalian, avian, and almost all machine stereo algorithms look for similarities between the luminance-defined images in the two eyes, using a series of computations to produce a map showing how depth varies across the scene. Stereopsis has also evolved in at least one invertebrate, the praying mantis. Mantis stereopsis is presumed to be simpler than vertebrates\u2019, but little is currently known about the underlying computations. Here, we show that mantis stereopsis uses a fundamentally different computational algorithm from vertebrate stereopsis\u2014rather than comparing luminance in the two eyes\u2019 images directly, mantis stereopsis looks for regions of the images where luminance is changing. Thus, while there is no evidence that mantis stereopsis works at all with static images, it successfully reveals the distance to a moving target even in complex visual scenes with targets that are perfectly camouflaged against the background in terms of texture. Strikingly, these insects outperform human observers at judging stereoscopic distance when the pattern of luminance in the two eyes does not match. Insect stereopsis has thus evolved to be computationally efficient while being robust to poor image resolution and to discrepancies in the pattern of luminance between the two eyes.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "5", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "149", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M40S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.012", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.012", "items": [{"id": "_5Nt7T8QOqs", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-05-25T20:45:48Z", "description": "Please be aware that the cross-section of the femoral neck is not oval but triangle. The best passway of a lag-screw (from the centre of shaft to the centre of the femoral head) is the posterior 1/3 at the femoral neck. It will be the bottom of the neck.\nOur paper is \nNakanishi Y, Hiranaka T, Shirahama M, et al. Ideal screw positions for multiple screw fixation in femoral neck fractures - Study of proximal femur morphology in a Japanese population. You hit the gym, you train hard, but the numbers barely move. You've hit a plateau.\n\nIn this video, I discuss six science-based ways to break through bench press plateaus so you can bench more weight for more reps, and continue to build a bigger, stronger chest.\n\nThese methods are not just theories or things I got from research papers. These are methods that I've used in practice to help experienced lifters get to the next level on their bench. These are the same methods I'd like to share with you.\n\n1. Using the right progression scheme \n2. Experimenting with different training frequencies \n3. Using Deloads \n4. Finding the sweet spot for total working sets per week \n5. Building larger muscles (to increase potential strength output) \n6. Focusing on recovery outside of the gym \n\nThanks for watching! \n\n--------- \n\nOnline Coaching: https://www.madegains.com/coaching/\n\n--------- \n\nReferences: \n1. Baker DG. 10-year changes in upper body strength and power in elite professional rugby league players--the effect of training age, stage, and content.
