Apr\u00e8s un passage rapide sur le stockage qui aura le droit \u00e0 d'autres vid\u00e9os, je parle du couplage sectoriel et du pilotage de la demande. Comme toutes les techniques abord\u00e9es ne sont pas suffisantes pour g\u00e9rer l'intermittence, il faut compl\u00e9ter la production avec des moyens de production pilotables.\n\nJe vous parle ensuite de l'effet des moyen de productions intermittent sur la structure du r\u00e9seau \u00e9lectrique, sur l'\u00e9quilibrage du r\u00e9seau \u00e9lectrique et sur son inertie. C'est le moment de se rendre compte que les moyens intermittents ne participent pas \u00e0 la stabilit\u00e9 du r\u00e9seau \u00e9lectrique ou \u00e0 sa r\u00e9sistance \u00e0 des perturbations. Je finis en parlant des co\u00fbts d'int\u00e9gration, de leur \u00e9volution en fonction du pourcentage de moyens intermittents et de la production \u00e9lectrique europ\u00e9enne.\n\nMerci \u00e0 @monsieur bidouille, une cha\u00eene que je vous recommande fortement et notamment cette vid\u00e9o: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mhZU6RWlyo0\n\n0:00 \u2022 Introduction\n2:28 \u2022 Stockage\n6:09 \u2022 Couplage sectoriel\n9:30 \u2022 Pilotage de la demande\n13:55 \u2022 Compl\u00e9ment avec des moyens de production pilotables\n18:37 \u2022 Effet des moyens intermittents sur la structure du r\u00e9seau\n20:03 \u2022 \u00c9quilibrage du r\u00e9seau \u00e9lectrique\n27:33 \u2022 Inertie du r\u00e9seau \u00e9lectrique\n31:03 \u2022 Co\u00fbts d'int\u00e9gration des moyens intermittents\n37:56 \u2022 Production \u00e9lectrique europ\u00e9enne\n\n_______________________\nSources d\u00e9taill\u00e9es et informations compl\u00e9mentaires ici: https://www.lereveilleur.com/eolien,-photovoltaique-et-reseau-electrique/\nLe texte est disponible ici:\nhttps://docs.google.com/document/d/1y9gZ3vuhpYBFR8n4HCF4m9JYKvvhF28D3MJ-f_RmFe0/edit?usp=sharing\n\n___________________\nSoutenir la cha\u00eene:\nhttps://en.tipeee.com/le-reveilleur\nhttps://www.utip.io/feed/lereveilleur\nhttps://takhotakh.com/chaine/324\n\n______________\nMerci \u00e0 Nicolas Goldberg que vous pouvez suivre ici: https://twitter.com/GoldbergNic pour b\u00e9n\u00e9ficier de son expertise.\nMerci \u00e0 Emile Fulcheri (https://twitter.com/EmileFulcheri) qui a longuement \u00e9chang\u00e9 avec moi.\nMerci \u00e0 Thomas Auriel (https://twitter.com/Thomas_Auriel) qui m'a aid\u00e9 \u00e0 m'en sortir avec les donn\u00e9es et produit l'excellent https://twitter.com/botelectricity.\nMerci \u00e9galement \u00e0 V. "description": "Taxonomic assignment: Amoebozoa: Discosea: Vannellida: Vannellidae\n\nPrimary reference: Kudryavtsev A, Volkova E (2018). Clydonella sawyeri n. sp. (Amoebozoa, Vannellida): Morphological and molecular study and a re-definition of the genus Clydonella Sawyer, 1975. Eur. J. Protistol. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejop.2018.01.008\n\nLocation: upper layer of muddy sand and organic detritus picked at low tide from the upper part of the littoral zone of Seldyanaya Bay, Chupa Inlet (Kandalaksha Bay, The White Sea, North-Western Russia; grid reference 66.3384387N, 33.618127E); salinity at the moment of sampling 22\u2030; sampling date: 15.07.2014\n\nReference culture: CCMA0009, kept with the Resource Centre \"Culture Collection of Microorganisms\" (Research Park, St-Petersburg State University); http://researchpark.spbu.ru/en/ccem-eng\n\nImaging: Leica DM2500 upright microscope 100x planapochromate oil immersion object lense with 1x camera adaptor, Leica DFC295 video camera, differential interference contrast.\n\nObservation conditions: Amoebae picked out from the culture, placed on a coverslip in a drop of medium and allowed to settle in a moist chamber. Then the coverslip is placed on a slide with the sealing vaseline border to prevent the preparation from drying out too quickly. The preparation is then placed on the microscope with the coverslip up. Observation starts immediately.\n\nContact: Dr. Alexander Kudryavtsev, St-Petersburg State University (alexander.kudryavtsev@spbu.ru)", "channelId": "UCRK3mXipI41tytxPpIC1qXQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "viewCount": "48", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M50S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.008", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.008", "items": [{"id": "_bvB8EMyOlU", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Jennifer Berne", "tags": ["unconscious bias training", "racism", "bias", "discrimination", "cultural competence"], "title": "Unconscious Bias Training:  Use and Misuse", "publishedAt": "2019-03-17T09:03:18Z", "description": "USC Doctoral candidate group video on Unconscious Bias Training and Cultural Competence.  Group explores the need for cultural bias sensitivity training, rationale behind UBT in particular, flaws and challenges to UBT, and possible means of implementation in corporations looking to decrease bias and increase diversity and cultural competency.", "channelId": "UCFjFejMZNuvSg-3rSSOOaZw"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "69", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M29S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "items": [{"id": "N-Ie-K-361Q", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Science Magazine", "tags": ["Science", "Magazine", "ray", "skate", "walking", "ambulatory", "locomotion"], "title": "Snippet: Watch a juvenile little skate walk with tiny legs", "publishedAt": "2018-02-08T19:08:28Z", "description": "How did animals go from swimming to walking--what changed about their bodies? Skates like this one use the same neurons to walk as land animals. Because skates are an evolutionarily ancient animal, that means the neurons essential for walking originated in species that separated from other four-legged vertebrates, or tetrapods, about 420 million years ago.  \n\nLearn more: http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/02/walking-fish-may-reveal-how-animals-first-took-land\n\nRead the paper: http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(18)30050-3\n\nAbout Science Snippets:\n\nThese videos are short snippets from researchers' work--often these videos are actually used as data in studies or to demonstrate results in a paper.  \n\nCREDITS\n\nproducer\nSarah Crespi\n\ncitation\nL. Jung et al., Cell 2018\nDOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2018.01.013\n\nvideo\nJeremy Dasen \n\nmusic\nAudioblocks", "channelId": "UCv0aU2eKry3kdSTnFa8QAWA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "159", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "6", "viewCount": "31695", "dislikeCount": "4"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M15S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "items": [{"id": "r53JpZMBnuQ", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "ScienceVio", "tags": ["Cell", "Leucoraja erinacea", "spinal cord", "motor neuron", "locomotion", "Hox gene", "neural circuit", "evolution", "development"], "title": "The Ancient Origins of Neural Substrates for Land Walking", "publishedAt": "2018-02-09T04:14:41Z", "description": "The Ancient Origins of Neural Substrates for Land Walking. Heekyung Jung et al (2018), Cell https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2018.01.013\n\nWalking is the predominant locomotor behavior expressed by land-dwelling vertebrates, but it is unknown when the neural circuits that are essential for limb control first appeared. Certain fish species display walking-like behaviors, raising the possibility that the underlying circuitry originated in primitive marine vertebrates. We show that the neural substrates of bipedalism are present in the little skate Leucoraja erinacea, whose common ancestor with tetrapods existed \u223c420 million years ago. Leucoraja exhibits core features of tetrapod locomotor gaits, including left-right alternation and reciprocal extension-flexion of the pelvic fins. Leucoraja also deploys a remarkably conserved Hox transcription factor-dependent program that is essential for selective innervation of fin/limb muscle. This network encodes peripheral connectivity modules that are distinct from those used in axial muscle-based swimming and has apparently been diminished in most modern fish. These findings indicate that the circuits that are essential for walking evolved through adaptation of a genetic regulatory network shared by all vertebrates with paired appendages.\n\nGood channel: https://www.youtube.com/Dlium\nSubscribe, like and comment.\n\nGood website: https://www.dlium.com\nBookmark, subscribe and comment.", "channelId": "UC32BboXfQ_tDCV8y1ttx7cg"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "118", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M54S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.013", "items": [{"id": "plMoka5bRfI", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Dr. Eric St-Onge", "tags": ["kettlebell", "kettlebell sport", "kettlebells", "kettlebell sport science", "mobility", "exercise", "technique", "Dr. Eric St-Onge", "Turkish Get-Up", "rccssc", "royal college of chiropractic sports sciences", "turkish get up", "turkish get-up kettlebell", "turkish get-up research", "research study", "get up", "functional fitness", "functional exercise", "Kettlebell Research", "Kettlebell Study", "Kettlebell Research Study", "shoulder exercise", "shoulder rehabilitation", "shoulder muscle exercise", "turkish get-up shoulder"], "title": "TURKISH GET-UP (the very FIRST SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH STUDY!)", "publishedAt": "2018-04-09T16:13:11Z", "description": "After nearly 3.5 years of work, my study has finally been published and I'm very happy to have contributed to kettlebell-related research!\n\nRead the FULL study here: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jbmt.2018.01.013\n\n--\nFOLLOW ME: \nInstagram: https://www.instagram.com/drericstonge/\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/drericstonge\nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/drericstonge\nWebsite: http://www.drericstonge.com\n---\nDISCLAIMER: This video is for educational purposes only. ["science", "neuroscience", "chemosensation", "research", "zebrafish", "animal behavior"], "title": "Zebrafish do not avoid taurocholic acid (TCA)", "publishedAt": "2018-02-01T08:21:35Z", "description": "Like us, fish need oxygen, and swimming through a patch of carbon dioxide turns out not to be a pleasant experience. Instead, they prefer to avoid carbon dioxide altogether. In experiments published in Cell Reports on Jan. 30, researchers at the RIKEN Brain Science Institute in Japan have discovered a neuronal pathway that makes this behavior possible. \n\nThis video shows that a 14 day post fertilization zebrafish larva has no problem swimming past TCA.\n\nReference:\nKoide T, Yabuki Y, Yoshihara Y (2018) Terminal nerve GnRH3 neurons mediate slow avoidance of carbon dioxide in larval zebrafish. Cell Reports. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2018.01.019", "channelId": "UCyE-1AI0fTrOsoYT-whBwoQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "84", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.019", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.019", "items": [{"id": "PMI-uMnT8cc", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "riken english channel", "tags": ["science", "zebrafish", "research", "neuroscience", "chemosensation", "carbon dioxide", "animal behavior"], "title": "Zebrafish avoid carbon dioxide", "publishedAt": "2018-02-01T08:20:13Z", "description": "Like us, fish need oxygen, and swimming through a patch of carbon dioxide turns out not to be a pleasant experience. Instead, they prefer to avoid carbon dioxide altogether. In experiments published in Cell Reports on Jan. 30, researchers at the RIKEN Brain Science Institute in Japan have discovered a neuronal pathway that makes this behavior possible. \n\nThis video shows a 14 day post fertilization zebrafish larva backing away from carbon dioxide.\nReference:\nKoide T, Yabuki Y, Yoshihara Y (2018) Terminal nerve GnRH3 neurons mediate slow avoidance of carbon dioxide in larval zebrafish. While other mammals have been previously cloned using this method, Zhong Zhong & Hua Hua are the first primate clones made by SCNT. Bai Chunli, president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS): \"The cloning of such non-human primates will offer a good animal model for the study of human diseases and health. It's a scientific research of pioneering significance made by Chinese scientists\". Zhong Zhong is about eight weeks old, ten days older than Hua Hua. Both are in stable conditions, according to the CAS. \n\nCredits\nVideo: China Central Television\nResearch:\nCloning of Macaque Monkeys by Somatic Cell Nuclear Transfer\nZhen Liu, Yijun Cai, Yan Visual Vertigo: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306987718301324\n\nhttps://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/21695717.2017.1347367\n\nOKN Training: Focus Builder focusbuilderapp.com", "channelId": "UCanHPRdxKtYvMRNl1DTGT6g", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "5", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "251", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT45M6S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.025", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.025", "items": [{"id": "ppAsK3qzDQc", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2018-09-21T09:26:50Z", "description": "Title: From Ecotoxicology to Ecology to Data Science and Statistics and back again: What Ecotoxicologists can Learn from Other Disciplines \u2013 and vice versa \n\nAbstract: Raoul will tell a story that brought him from the safe shores of ecotoxicology to the wilderness of ecology, staying (arguably) sane in the multiverse of data science and resisting the sweet serenades of the sirens of statistics, only to end up where he has started his journey: ecotoxicology. He will present selected studies from his PhD, which showcase the potential synergies of ecotoxicology linking up with neighboring disciplines, such as limnology and physico-chemical modelling. He will show how two environmental stressors, ultraviolet radiation and water browning, interact and cause genetic damages in zooplankton. The harmful potential of these two environmental stressors is then assessed by modelling their effect interaction for 77 Scandinavian lakes, with surprising results. On the ecosystem-scale, he will present a case study of combined effects of ultraviolet radiation and water browning from the Norwegian midlands, and how they affect species distribution in an alpine landscape. In the end he will recap his journey, summarizing his experience working between disciplines and how this has prepared him for the tasks ahead in his post doc. Will he be able to tell all of this in just 20 minutes? Come and find out! \n\nBiography: Raoul is a biologist with a strong background in ecotoxicology and data analysis, and recently started his post doc position at NIVA\u2019s Section for Ecotoxicology and Risk Assessment. He defended his PhD in early 2018, and will present some of his findings during the faglunsj. Now back on ecotoxicological home turf he works \u2013 amongst other things \u2013 on NIVA\u2019s risk assessment database (RAdb) and the implementation of modern statistical approaches in the effect assessment of complex mixtures and multiple stressors as part of the MixRisk project. Raoul is also active in Oslo\u2019s useR community, giving regular workshops on how to use open-source statistical software R for reproducible research. \n\nLinks: \nWolf R, Andersen T, Hessen DO, Hylland K. 2016. "tags": ["better to be an introvert", "introversion is better", "introversion", "extraversion", "popularity", "socializing", "six facets", "warmth", "gregariousness", "assertiveness", "activity", "excitement seeking", "positive emotions", "FFM", "big five", "five-factor model", "mental health", "counseling", "extroversion"], "title": "6 Ways Introversion is better than Extraversion | The Upside of Low Extraversion", "publishedAt": "2019-12-26T20:58:08Z", "description": "This video answers the questions: Are there ways that low extraversion is better than high extraversion? (Is there an upside to being an introvert as opposed to being an extrovert?) \n\nOne of the things we hear about extraversion all the time is how it\u2019s more socially desirable. Research supports this general concept, that all things being equal, high extraversion imparts advantages at a social level. However, just because extraversion is more socially desirable doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s more desirable in every way. \n\nI cover the six ways being an introvert is better and align these ways with the six facets of extraversion.\n\nThe six facets of extraversion:\n\n1. Warmth: friendly, kind\n2. Gregariousness: talkative, spontaneous, outgoing\n3. Assertiveness: confident, enthusiastic, aggressive, dominating\n4. Activity: energetic, always want to be busy, in a hurry \n5. Excitement-seeking: adventurous, courageous, bold\n6. Positive Emotions: optimistic, cheerful, happy\n\n\nFurnham, A., & Cheng, H. (2018). CEPID", "tags": ["Ruthenium complexes", "ROMP", "ATRP", "Norbornene", "Methyl methacrylate", "research", "brazil", "materials", "ufscar", "sao carlos", "cdmf"], "title": "Accessible ring opening metathesis and atom transfer radical polymerization catalysts...", "publishedAt": "2018-08-22T17:45:55Z", "description": "Accessible ring opening metathesis and atom transfer radical polymerization catalysts based on dimethyl sulfoxide ruthenium(II) complexes bearing N-heterocyclic carbene ligands\n\nAbstract\nDimethyl sulfoxide ruthenium(II) complexes of N-heterocyclic carbenes derived from cycloalkylamines (cycloalkyl\u202f=\u202fcyclopentyl (1a), cyclohexyl (1b), cycloheptyl (1c), and cyclooctyl (1d)) were synthesized: [RuCl2(S-dmso)2(IPent)] (2a), [RuCl2(S-dmso)2(IHex)] (2b), [RuCl2(S-dmso)2(IHept)] (2c), and [RuCl2(S-dmso)2(IOct)] (2d). The imidazolium salts 1a-1d were characterized by FTIR, UV\u2013vis, and 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, while their respective dimethyl sulfoxide ruthenium(II) complexes (2a-2d) were characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR, UV\u2013vis, 1H and 13C NMR, and cyclic voltammetry. The complexes 2a-2d were evaluated as catalytic precursors for ROMP of norbornene (NBE) and for ATRP of methyl methacrylate (MMA). The polynorbornene (polyNBE) syntheses via ROMP using the complexes 2a-2d as pre-catalysts were evaluated under reaction conditions of [EDA]/[Ru]\u202f=\u202f28 (5\u202f\u03bcL), [NBE]/[Ru]\u202f=\u202f5000 at 50\u202f\u00b0C as a function of time. The polymerization of MMA via ATRP was conducted using the complexes 2a-2d in the presence of ethyl 2-bromoisobutyrate (EBiB) as the initiator. All tests were using the molar ratio [MMA]/[EBiB]/[Ru]\u202f=\u202f1000/2/1 and conducted at 85\u202f\u00b0C. The linear correlation of ln([MMA]0/[MMA]) and time clearly indicates that the concentration of radicals remains constant during the polymerization and that the ATRP of MMA mediated by 2a-2d proceeds in a controlled manner.\n\nAuthors: Andr\u00e9 H.S. Cartailler, T. Know, R. Yuste and D. Holcman, Deconvolution of Voltage Sensor Time Series and Electro-diffusion Modeling Reveal the Role of Spine Geometry in Controlling Synaptic Strength\u201d Neuron. 2018 Mar 7;97(5):1126-1136.e10. doi:\u00a010.1016/j.neuron.2018.01.034.", "channelId": "UCIUgKaD5QB5LoqdJwhYFR2g"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "35", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT21M47S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.034", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.034", "items": [{"id": "GpbMd4H_Izg", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Society for AI and Deep Learning", "title": "AI for India and Beyond by Manish Gupta", "publishedAt": "2020-08-01T20:57:27Z", "description": "Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI), especially the field of machine learning (ML), is transforming virtually all aspects of our lives. This talk describes our preliminary efforts at Google Research India to tackle problems arising in the Indian context and beyond. We start with examples of opportunities to apply ML to accelerate science and its applications, and some early results. We then describe a critical need and an opportunity to improve health outcomes globally at lower costs, and specific challenges in countries like India of an acute shortage of doctors. As examples, we describe a convolutional neural network based solution developed by our researchers for more effective screening of diabetic retinopathy, as well as ongoing efforts towards prevention of cardiovascular disease. We describe our AI for Social Good program through which we are addressing issues like public health, education and wildlife conservation, in partnership with NGOs and academic researchers. We describe challenges arising due to factors like diversity of languages and code mixing for Google products like Search and Assistant, which are being used daily by tens of millions of users in India, and our natural language processing research. Finally, we describe outstanding challenges associated with the overall field of AI itself, like safety, data privacy, and fairness, and our guiding principles and directions to address them. \n\nBio: Manish Gupta is the Director of Google Research India, a new AI research lab recently announced by Google. He holds an additional appointment as Infosys Foundation Chair Professor at IIIT Bangalore. Previously, Manish has led VideoKen, a video technology startup, and the research centers for Xerox and IBM in India. As a Senior Manager at the IBM T.J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, New York, Manish led the team developing system software for the Blue Gene/L supercomputer. IBM was awarded a National Medal of Technology and Innovation for Blue Gene by US President Barack Obama in 2009. Manish holds a Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign. He has co-authored about 75 papers, with more than 7,000 citations in Google Scholar (and an h-index of 45), and has been granted 19 US patents. While at IBM, Manish received two Outstanding Technical Achievement Awards, an Outstanding Innovation Award and the Lou Gerstner Team Award for Client Excellence. Manish is a Fellow of ACM and the Indian National Academy of Engineering, and a recipient of a Distinguished Alumnus Award from IIT Delhi.", "channelId": "UCU5Pl1RJvrfwegSciyNdH5Q"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "36", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H13M22S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.036", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.036", "items": [{"id": "TrSTwH1Rpjs", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "de", "channelTitle": "Kai Mainzer", "tags": ["yt:cc=on"], "title": "The RE\u00b3ASON model for the analysis and optimization of urban energy systems", "publishedAt": "2017-06-29T19:40:47Z", "description": "RE\u00b3ASON: Renewable Energies and Energy Efficiency Analysis and System OptimizatioN\n\nChapters:\n00:05 Introduction & definition of assessment area using OSM data\n01:00 Analysis of energy infrastructure\n01:46 Analysis of energy demand\n02:50 Analysis of PV potentials\n05:40 Analysis of wind potentials\n08:27 Analysis of biomass potentials\n10:33 Optimization of the urban energy system\n\n\nRelated scientific publications:\n\nMainzer, Kai; Fath, Karoline; McKenna, Russell; Stengel, Julian; Fichtner, Wolf; Schultmann, Frank (2014): A high-resolution determination of the technical potential for residential-roof-mounted photovoltaic systems in Germany. Sfakianakis", "tags": ["Endoscopic", "endonasal", "craniofacial", "surgery", "for", "recurrent", "skull", "base", "meningiomas", "involving", "the", "pterygopalatine", "fossa", "infratemporal", "orbit", "and", "paranasal", "sinus"], "title": "Endoscopic endonasal craniofacial surgery for recurrent skull base meningiomas", "publishedAt": "2018-01-18T15:07:59Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEndoscopic endonasal craniofacial surgery for recurrent skull base meningiomas involving the pterygopalatine fossa, the infratemporal fossa, the orbit, and the paranasal sinus.\r\nShin M1, Shojima M2, Kondo K3, Hasegawa H2, Hanakita S2, Ito A2, Kin T2, Saito N2.\r\nAuthor information\r\n1\r\nDepartment of Neurosurgery. Electronic address: SHIN-NSU@h.u-tokyo.ac.jp.\r\n2\r\nDepartment of Neurosurgery.\r\n3\r\nDepartment of Otolaryngology, the University of Tokyo Hospital, Tokyo, Japan.\r\nAbstract\r\nOBJECT:\r\nSkull base meningiomas carry a non-negligible risk of recurrence. In particular, those arising from the sphenoid wings or middle cranial fossa penetrate into extracranial regions, uncommonly showing massive expansion into the craniofacial regions on recurrence. The role of endoscopic endonasal surgery for those intractable lesions remains unclear.\r\n\r\nMETHODS:\r\nWe performed endoscopic endonasal craniofacial surgery for 8 recurrent meningiomas invading into the pterygopalatine fossa, infratemporal fossa, nasopharynx, paranasal sinus, or orbit, comprising 2 meningothelial and 1 fibrous meningiomas (WHO grade I), 3 atypical and 1 clear cell meningiomas (grade II), and 1 anaplastic meningioma (grade III). All of they are large (15 cm3 to 80 cm3, median 45 cm3) and highly vascularized.\r\n\r\nRESULTS:\r\nAll the 8 tumors were sufficiently resected. Gross total resection of the craniofacial part of the lesions was achieved in 5 patients (62.5%). In 3 patients with WHO grade I meningiomas and 1 with grade II, tumors were successfully controlled as of the last follow-up. In 4 with WHO grade II or III meningiomas, craniofacial lesions were controlled, whereas original intracranial lesions were poorly controlled and became critical.\r\n\r\nCONCLUSIONS:\r\nWe consider endoscopic endonasal approach as an acceptable, less-invasive alternative for recurrent craniofacial meningioma. While all of these cases were relatively large and highly vascularized, preoperative endovascular embolization of the feeding arteries contributes to significantly reducing vascularity of the tumors, and local control of the craniofacial lesions was successfully achieved in all cases. Endoscopic endonasal craniofacial surgery enabled sufficient mass reduction without disfiguring facial incisions.\r\n\r\nCopyright \u00a9 2018 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.\r\n\r\nKEYWORDS:\r\natypical meningioma; craniofacial meningioma; craniofacial surgery; endoscopic endonasal craniofacial surgery; endoscopic endonasal surgery; infratemporal fossa; infratemporal fossa pterygopalatine fossa; orbit; pterygopalatine fossa; sanaplastic meningioma; skull base meningioma\r\n\r\nPMID: 29339322 DOI: 10.1016/j.wneu.2018.01.041\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelId": "UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "32", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M16S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.047", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2018.01.047", "items": [{"id": "1BipTQXJ4qE", "snippet": {"publishedAt": "2020-05-18T01:51:28Z", "description": "Histolog\u00eda del tejido \u00f3seo desmineralizado.Osteonas o sistemas de Havers, sistemas circunferenciales externos e internos. There was resulting public outcry, eventually leading to all hallucinogens being listed as schedule I drugs Common hallucinogens include: LSD (acid), Mescaline (peyote), DMT (ayahuasca), Psilocybin (mushrooms), MDMA (ecstacy) Effects vary by specific drug but may include auditory/visual hallucinations, increased empathy, loss of fear Physiologic effects often include mydriasis, tachycardia, hyperthermia and hypertension  Recent neuroimaging studies have shown increased neural connectivity in people after administration of hallucinogens Each hallucinogen has a specific dose and duration, some can last half a day or more    \r\n\r\n References\r\n\r\n Heal DJ, Gosden J, Smith SL. [{"id": "2hOUUF5dy4s", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en-GB", "channelTitle": "seaarch", "tags": ["Laos", "Luang Prabang", "Pak Ou Caves", "Drone", "Rock Art", "Archaeology", "Mekong", "Parrot Bebop"], "title": "Rock art at the cave of a thousand Buddhas, Luang Prabang, Lao PDR", "publishedAt": "2018-01-11T07:16:30Z", "description": "The Pak Ou Caves in Luang Prabang are famous for their Buddha statues, but do you know there's also rock art in the caves as well as on the cliff face? This video is part of the supplementary materials for the research article - a drone survey of the cliff face with a view of some of the oldest paintings at the site. Shot with a Parrot Bebop.\n\nRock art at the cave of a thousand Buddhas, Luang Prabang, Lao PDR\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ara.2018.01.001\n\nThe rock art of the Pak Ou Caves in Luang Prabang, Lao PDR has been known for over 20 years, but to date a complete record of the site has not been made. This paper presents an inventory of the rock art found at site also known as the Cave of a Thousand Buddhas. Over 50 rock art elements, mostly paintings, have been found in the upper cave and on the cliff face overlooking the junction of the Mekong and Ou Rivers. The oldest red paintings depict domesticated buffalo, human figures and hand prints and bear similarities with other cliff-side rock art sites in highland Southeast Asia. Other paintings are associated with the conversion of the cave into a Buddhist shrine, which according to folk tradition was home to a powerful river spirit. The most recent paintings can be comfortably dated to the 20th century. The Pak Ou Caves are a significant Buddhist site today, but the variety of rock art suggests its significance predates the Buddhist period that began in the 15th century. The layered history of the site and its rock art attests to multiple episodes of site use and re-use, from possibly the Neolithic until today.", "channelId": "UC51QJiAAN20LOCtSXuJAetg", "defaultLanguage": "en-GB"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "viewCount": "99", "dislikeCount": "0"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M29S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "LWsY4ovp7dk", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "pt", "channelTitle": "Hemocentro RP", "tags": ["RNA", "Melanoma", "genoma", "RNA longo", "Centro de Terapia Celular", "Hemocentro RP", "FMRP", "USP"], "title": "Semin\u00e1rios CTC - Profa. Take a journey through the animal kingdom with us and discover things you never knew before, or rediscover your favorite animals!\n\nGet More National Geographic Wild: \nOfficial Site: http://bit.ly/NatGeoWILD\nFacebook: http://bit.ly/NGWFacebook\nTwitter: http://bit.ly/NGWTwitter\nInstagram: http://bit.ly/NGWInstagram\n\nWhen little bumps all over their skin, called papillae, stick out, two kinds of muscles are involved in the display. One kind, striated muscles\u2014like skeletal muscles, such as your biceps\u2014help the cuttlefish raise the spiny nubs fast. Another kind, which are similar to the smooth muscles in your gut, seem to allow the bumps to stay up for as long as an hour without using much energy. Gonzales-Bellido and her collaborators also discovered that the a secondary nerve bundle, not the brain, controls the muscles, which hints at a deep evolutionary connection to a similar neural circuit in squid.\n\nRead the related article \"Cuttlefish Pretend to be Crabs to Catch More Fish.\"\nhttps://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/cuttlefish-mimics-hermit-crabs-catch-fish/\n\nCuttlefish Look Like Squid\u2014and Like Crabs, and Like Algae, and Like Rocks | Nat Geo Wild\nhttps://youtu.be/qFEV4K9hUq8\n\nNat Geo Wild \nhttps://www.youtube.com/user/NatGeoWild", "channelId": "UCDPk9MG2RexnOMGTD-YnSnA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "387", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "22", "viewCount": "15929", "dislikeCount": "6"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M5S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "ZQf_1dHGdlY", "snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "fr", "channelTitle": "Dr Astuce", "tags": ["dr", "astuce", "clair", "medecine", "cours", "explication", "paces", "residanat", "internat", "motivation", "exams", "pr\u00e9paration exams", "pr\u00e9parer examens", "effet hemingway", "effet zeigarnik", "effet ovsiankina"], "title": "\ud83d\udd34 Comment \u00eatre Motiv\u00e9 pour les cours autant que pour Netflix", "publishedAt": "2019-12-21T17:00:08Z", "description": "Cette m\u00e9thode a \u00e9t\u00e9 d\u00e9couverte en 2018 par des chercheurs japonais, je l'ai utilis\u00e9e pendant des mois avec beaucoup de succ\u00e8s !\n\nsource : https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S187118711730189X\n\r\nwww.drastuce.com\r\n\r\n..::: Dr Astuce :::...\r\n\r\n - Sauver Une Vie Commence ici -", "channelId": "UCzepGf1Ls1B47MdWeJwR9ig", "defaultLanguage": "fr"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4180", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "215", "viewCount": "63942", "dislikeCount": "79"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M59S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.001", "items": [{"id": "epAnsWDVMQQ", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Otolaryngologist,ORL,ENT-Medical Office,Artz Praxis", "tags": ["Treatment", "of", "chronic", "tinnitus", "Transcranial", "direct", "current", "stimulation"], "title": "Treatment of chronic tinnitus : Transcranial direct current stimulation", "publishedAt": "2018-01-08T13:20:15Z", "description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\nEffect of transcranial direct current stimulation on short-term and long-term treatment of chronic tinnitus\r\nHamidreza Abtahi, Ahmadreza Okhovvat, Somaiie Heidari, Azar Gharagazarloo, Motahare Mirdamadi, Mohammad Hossein Nilforoush, Hossein Ghazavi'Correspondence information about the author Hossein GhazaviEmail the author Hossein Ghazavi\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.amjoto.2018.01.001\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nReferences\r\nAbstract\r\nObjective\r\nThis study was conducted to investigate the effectiveness of anodal and cathodal methods in reducing the intensity of tinnitus and to compare them with the control.\r\n\r\nMethodology\r\nThis randomized double-blind clinical trial with case and control groups was conducted in Al-Zahra Hospital in Isfahan between 2015 and 2016. In this trial, 51 patients with tinnitus, for at least one year, were selected among those outpatients visiting the throat, nose and ear clinic within this period. Inclusion criteria were patients on electrical stimulation prohibition, with M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease, otosclerosis, chronic headache, and pulsatile tinnitus. Patients were randomly divided in three equal-sized groups: anodal stimulation group, cathodal stimulation group, and control group. The subjects received 20-min current stimulation (2\u202fmA). Five subjects were selected from those with a significant difference between the stimulated states (anodal or cathodal) and/or control. They received weekly transcranial electrical stimulation for two months, and their long-term recovery from tinnitus was investigated. Data analysis was done with SPSS20.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nFindings showed no significant between-groups difference in mean scores of tinnitus before the intervention (p\u202f=\u202f.68); whereas, this difference was significant immediately after the intervention (p\u202f=\u202f.02) and 1\u202fh after it (p\u202f=\u202f.03). The mean score of tinnitus in the anodal stimulation group was significantly lower than the control; whereas, no significant difference was observed between the anodal and cathodal stimulation groups, and between the cathodal and control groups (p\u202f\u202f.05). Findings also showed that the mean scores of tinnitus in two cathodal stimulation groups (p\u202f=\u202f.24) and control group (p\u202f=\u202f.62) were not significantly different at three different points of time; whereas, this score was significantly different in the anodal group at these time points (p\u202f=\u202f.01).\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nIn conclusion, anodal stimulation was more effective than the cathodal and control stimulation in reducing the intensity of tinnitus in the short term.\r\n\r\nKeywords:\r\nTinnitus, Cathodal stimulation, Anodal stimulation, Transcranial direct current stimulation\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelId": "UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "255", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M56S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.005", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.005", "items": [{"id": "FtnfsK3QzYs", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "Emagrecer De Vez", "tags": ["emagrecer de vez", "alimentacao forte", "rodrigo polesso", "figado gordo", "detox", "limpar o figado"], "title": "REMOVA ESTES 4 ALIMENTOS Para Limpar o Fi\u0301gado Ra\u0301pido | Detox Pro F\u00edgado | Limpar F\u00edgado Gordo", "publishedAt": "2020-08-26T13:00:03Z", "description": "Pessoal, hoje trago pra voc\u00ea dicas do que comer e n\u00e3o comer para limpar o f\u00edgado rapidamente e naturalmente sem medicamentos. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\nhttp://www.sleep-journal.com/article/S1389-9457(18)30017-0/fulltext?rss=yes\r\n\r\nChildhood sleep and adolescent chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME): evidence of associations in a UK birth cohort\r\nSimon M. Collin, Tom Norris, Paul Gringras, Peter S. Blair, Kate Tilling, Esther Crawley'Correspondence information about the author Esther CrawleyEmail the author Esther Crawley\r\nOpen Access\r\nDOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.sleep.2018.01.005\r\nOpen access funded by Medical Research Council\r\n\r\nhideArticle Info\r\nPublication History\r\nPublished online: February 01, 2018\r\nAccepted: January 8, 2018\r\nReceived in revised form: January 6, 2018\r\nReceived: April 25, 2017\r\nUser License\r\nCreative Commons Attribution (CC BY 4.0) How you can reuse  Information Icon\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nSupplemental Materials\r\nArticle Outline\r\n1. Associations of sleep duration with CDF\r\n3.2.1. Sleep at age 9 and CDF at age 13\r\n3.2.2. Sleep at age 11 and CDF at age 16\r\n4. Discussion\r\nStrengths and weaknesses\r\nOur findings in the context of the studies\r\n5. Conclusions and future work\r\nFunding\r\nAcknowledgement\r\nAppendix A. Supplementary data\r\nReferences\r\nGoHighlights\r\n\u2022Children who develop chronic disabling fatigue (CDF) in adolescence have shorter nighttime sleep duration throughout early childhood.\r\n\u2022For each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 9, the odds of CDF at age 13 were 40% lower, and for each additional hour at age 11, the odds of CDF at age 16 were 50% lower.\r\n\u2022Sleep abnormalities may have a causal role in CFS/ME, or sleep abnormalities and CFS/ME are related to a common pathophysiological cause.\r\nGoAbstract\r\nObjective\r\n/Background: Sleep abnormalities are characteristic of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS, also known as \u2018ME\u2019), but it is not known whether sleep might be a causal risk factor for CFS/ME.\r\n\r\nPatients/Methods\r\nWe analysed data from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC) birth cohort. We describe sleep patterns from age 6 months to 11 years in children who were subsequently classified as having (or not having) \u2018chronic disabling fatigue\u2019 (CDF, a proxy for CFS/ME) between ages 13-18 years, and investigate associations of sleep duration at age 9 with CDF at age 13, and sleep duration at age 11 with CDF at age 16 years.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nChildren who had CDF during adolescence had shorter nighttime sleep duration from age 6 months to age 11 years, and there was strong evidence that difficulties in going to sleep were more common in children who subsequently developed CDF. The odds of CDF at age 13 were 39% lower (odds ratio (OR) = 0.61, 95% CI 0.43, 0.88) for each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 9 years, and the odds of CDF at age 16 were 51% lower (OR = 0.49, 95% CI 0.34, 0.70) for each additional hour of nighttime sleep at age 11. Mean nighttime sleep duration at age 9 was 13.9 (95% CI 3.75, 24.0) minutes shorter among children who developed CDF at age 13, and sleep duration at age 11 was 18.7 (95% CI 9.08, 28.4) minutes shorter among children who developed CDF at age 16 (compared with children who did not develop CDF at 13 and 16, respectively).\r\n\r\nConclusions\r\nChildren who develop chronic disabling fatigue in adolescence have shorter nighttime sleep duration throughout early childhood, suggesting that sleep abnormalities may have a causal role in CFS/ME or that sleep abnormalities and CFS/ME are related to a common pathophysiological cause.\r\n\r\nKeywords:\r\npaediatric, adolescence, chronic fatigue syndrome, CFS/ME, sleep, ALSPAC\r\nGo1. Background\r\nChronic fatigue syndrome (CFS, also known as \u2018ME\u2019) in children and young people is a debilitating disease with an adverse impact on the lives of children and their families [[1], [2], [3]]. UK National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines state that diagnosis of CFS/ME should be made after 3 months of persistent or recurrent fatigue which is not the result of ongoing exertion, not s", "channelId": "UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "24", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M41S"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.005", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2018.01.005", "items": [{"id": "nix6Mvu5ZQg", "snippet": {"channelTitle": "The Science of Self-Care", "tags": ["placebo", "the science of self-care", "science", "selfcare", "nutrition", "face mask", "skincare", "health", "well-being", "placebo effect", "mind", "power", "mindset", "experimentation", "wellness"], "title": "PLAY WITH PLACEBOS (take action and relieve health issues) // The Science of Self-Care", "publishedAt": "2019-06-28T22:04:37Z", "description": "Though this channel is science-based, not all of our self-care rituals need to be in order to reap real health benefits. \n\nI am so excited to finally touch upon a fascinating phenomenon: the placebo effect! \n\nThough placebos are typically neglected in science / used as negative controls, they are very powerful means to achieving positive health outcomes. \n\nI hope you enjoy this broad introduction to placebos and more importantly, I urge you to keep taking action to support your health and happiness.
